Paragraph: Ad reliqua transeamus animalia et primum terrestria. Nutrierat eum puer dilectum admodum, parens que serpentis naturam et magnitudinem metuens in solitudines tulerat, in quibus circumvento latronum insidiis agnito que voce subvenit. Nam quae de infantibus ferarum lacte nutritis, cum essent expositi, produntur, sicut de conditoribus nostris a lupa, magnitudini fatorum accepta fieri aequius quam ferarum naturae arbitror.
english_text: Democritus also gives credence to this, who tells of Thoante being saved by a dragon in Arcadia. He had nursed him as a very beloved child, whose parents, fearing the nature and size of the serpent, had taken him into the deserts, where he was surrounded by the snares of robbers, recognizing that he would come to his aid by voice. For the children of wild beasts, when they were exposed, are betrayed, as our founders were by the she-wolf.

Paragraph: Panthera et tigris macularum varietate prope solae bestiarum spectantur, ceteris unus ac suus cuique generi color est, leonum tantum in Syria niger. Pantheris in candido breves macularum oculi. Ferunt odore earum mire sollicitari quadripedes cunctas, sed capitis torvitate terreri; quam ob rem occultato eo reliqua dulcedine invitatas corripiunt. Sunt qui tradant in armo iis similem lunae esse maculam crescentem in orbem se que cavantem pari modo.
english_text: Panthers and tigers are seen to be almost the only animals with a variety of spots, the rest being one and its own color for each race, the lions only being black in Syria. Panthers in white with short eye spots. All quadrupeds are said to be strangely alarmed by their smell, but to be terrified by the dizziness of the head; for which reason, concealing the matter, they rebuke those who were invited with the rest of the sweetness. There are those who say that in their arms there is a spot similar to the moon growing into the orb and hollowing itself out in the same way.

Paragraph: Nunc varias et pardos, qua mares sunt, appellant in eo omni genere, creberrimo in Africa Syria que. Quidam ab his pantheras candore solo discernunt, nec adhuc aliam differentiam inveni.
english_text: Now there are various species and leopards, which are males, they call in every kind, the most numerous in Africa, Syria. Some distinguish panthers from these by the whiteness of the ground, and I have not yet found any other difference.

Paragraph: Senatus consultum fuit vetus, ne liceret Africanas in Italiam advehere. Contra hoc tulit ad populum Cn. Aufidius tribunus plebis permisit que circensium gratia inportare. Primus autem Scaurus aedilitate sua varias CL universas misit, dein Pompeius Magnus CCCCX, Divus Augustus CCCCXX.
english_text: The senate was of old opinion, that it should not be permitted to bring Africans into Italy. Against this he brought to the people Cn. Aufidius, the tribune of the people, allowed them to bring in the grace of the circuses. The first Scaurus, with his aedilium, sent 150 different legions, then Pompeius the Great 330, and Divus Augustus 3320.

Paragraph: Idem Q. Tuberone Paulo Fabio Maximo cos. IIII non. Mai. theatri Marcelli dedicatione tigrim primus omnium Romae ostendit in cavea mansuefactam, Divus vero Claudius simul IIII.
english_text: The same Q. Tuberone Paulus Fabius Maximus cos. No. 4 May At the dedication of the theater, Marcellus was the first of all in Rome to show the tiger tamed in a cage, but the giant Claudius at the same time III.

Paragraph: Tigrim Hyrcani et Indi ferunt, animal velocitatis tremendae et maxime cognitae, dum capitur totus eius fetus, qui semper numerosus est. ab insidiante rapitur equo quam maxime pernici atque in recentes subinde transfertur. At ubi vacuum cubile reperit feta (maribus enim subolis cura non est), fertur praeceps odore vestigans. Raptor adpropinquante fremitu abicit unum ex catulis; tollit illa morsu et pondere etiam ocior acta remeat iterum que consequitur ac subinde, donec in navem regresso inrita feritas saevit in litore.
english_text: The Hyrcans and the Indians carry the tiger, an animal of tremendous speed and the best known, while all its offspring, which are always numerous, are captured. he is carried away by the ambusher on a horse as perishable as possible, and is transferred from time to time to the fresh ones. But when the foal finds an empty bed (for the males do not care about the cubs), it is carried off with a swift trail of scent. The raptor, approaching with a roar, throws away one of the cubs; he removed it with a bite, and with the weight he rowed even more quickly, which followed, and from time to time, until, returning to the ship, the wild beast raged on the shore.

Paragraph: Camelos inter armenta pascit oriens, quarum duo genera, Bactriae et Arabiae; differunt, quod illae bina habent tubera in dorso, hae singula et sub pectore alterum, cui incumbant. Dentium superiore ordine, ut boves, carent in utroque genere. Omnes autem iumentorum ministeriis dorso funguntur atque etiam equitatus in proeliis.
english_text: The east feeds camels among herds, of which there are two kinds, the Bactrian and the Arabian; they differ in that they have two tubercles on their backs, these one each, and the other under the breast, on which they lean. The upper order of teeth, as in cattle, is wanting in both species. Now all are employed in the service of cattle, and also of cavalry in battle.

Paragraph: Velocitas ut equo, sed sua cuique mensura sicuti vires. Nec ultra adsuetum procedit spatium nec plus instituto onere recipit. Odium adversus equos gerunt naturale. Sitim et quadriduo tolerant inplentur que, cum bibendi occasio est, et in praeteritum et in futurum, obturbata proculcatione prius aqua: aliter potu non gaudent. Vivunt quinquagenis annis, quaedam et centenis. Vtrimque rabiem et ipsae sentiunt. Castrandi genus etiam feminas, quae bello praeparentur, inventum est: fortiores ita fiunt coitu negato.
english_text: Speed ​​as a horse, but to each his own measure as strength. He does not go beyond the usual distance, nor does he receive more of the prescribed burden. They have a natural hatred against horses. They tolerate thirst and are filled for four days, and when there is an opportunity to drink, both in the past and in the future, they are disturbed by the water first: otherwise they do not enjoy drinking. They live fifty years, some even hundreds. Both sides feel the rage themselves. A kind of castration has also been found in women who are prepared for war: thus they become stronger by being denied intercourse.

Paragraph: Harum aliqua similitudo in duo transfertur animalia. Nabun Aethiopes vocant collo similem equo, pedibus et cruribus bovi, camelo capite, albis maculis rutilum colorem distinguentibus, unde appellata camelopardalis, dictatoris Caesaris circensibus ludis primum visa Romae. Ex eo subinde cernitur, aspectu magis quam feritate conspicua, quare etiam ovis ferae nomen invenit.
english_text: Some resemblance of these is transferred to the two animals. Nabun, the Ethiopians call him, has a neck like a horse, feet and legs like an ox, a camel's head, with white spots distinguishing its red color, whence it was called camelopardalis, first seen in Rome at the circus games of the dictator Caesar. From it it is seen from time to time, more visible in appearance than in ferocity, which is why it also found the name of wild sheep.

Paragraph: Pompei Magni primum ludi ostenderunt chama, quem Galli rufium vocabant, effigie lupi, pardorum maculis. Iidem ex Aethiopia quas vocant khvpouç, quarum pedes posteriores pedibus humanis et cruribus, priores manibus fuere similes. hoc animal postea Roma non vidit.
english_text: Pompeii the Great first exhibited the chama, which the Gauls called rufius, in the shape of a wolf, with the spots of a panther. The same from Ethiopia they call khvpouç, whose hind feet are like human feet and legs, and the former are like hands. Rome did not see this animal afterwards.

Paragraph: Isdem ludis et rhinoceros unius in nare cornus, qualis saepe, visus. alter hic genitus hostis elephanto cornu ad saxa limato praeparat se pugnae, in dimicatione alvum maxime petens, quam scit esse molliorem. Longitudo ei par, crura multo breviora, color buxeus.
english_text: In the same game, a rhinoceros with a horn on its nose, as it often did, was seen. the other born enemy prepares himself for battle with an elephant's horn filed against the rocks, in the battle seeking especially the bowels, which he knows to be softer. He was equal in length, his legs were much shorter, and his color was chestnut.

Paragraph: Lyncas vulgo frequentes et sphingas, fusco pilo, mammis in pectore geminis, Aethiopia generat multa que alia monstris similia, pinnatos equos et cornibus armatos, quos pegasos vocant, crocotas velut ex cane lupo que conceptos, omnia dentibus frangentes protinus que devorata conficientes ventre, cercopithecos nigris capitibus, pilo asini et dissimiles ceteris voce, Indicos boves unicornes tricornes que, leucrocotam, pernicissimam feram asini feri magnitudine, clunibus cervinis, collo, cauda, pectore leonis, capite melium, bisulca ungula, ore ad aures usque rescisso, dentium locis osse perpetuo (hanc feram humanas voces tradunt imitari.
english_text: Commonly numerous lynxes and sphinxes, with brown fur, mammoths in the breast of a twin, Ethiopia breeds many other similar monsters, finned horses and armed with horns, which they call pegasus, crocots as if from a wolf-dog, which they conceive, breaking everything with their teeth as soon as they are devoured, making their stomachs, cercopithecs with black heads, the hair of an ass, and unlike the rest of the voice, three-horned Indian oxen, leucrocote, the most destructive beast of the size of an ass, with the hips of a deer, the neck, tail, chest of a lion, the head of a honeybee, bisulky hooves, mouth to ear split open, the places of the teeth perpetually bone (This beast is taught to imitate human voices.

Paragraph: Apud eosdem et quae vocatur eale, magnitudine equi fluviatilis, cauda elephanti, colore nigra vel fulva, maxillis apri, maiora cubitalibus cornua habens mobilia, quae alterna in pugna sistit variat que infesta aut obliqua, utcumque ratio monstravit),
english_text: Among them also what is called an eale, the size of a river horse, the tail of an elephant, of a black or yellow color, with the jaws of a boar, and having movable horns greater than the cubits, which alternately stands in battle, varies from being aggressive or oblique, according as reason has shown.)

Paragraph: sed atrocissimos tauros silvestres, maiores agrestibus, velocitate ante omnes, colore fulvos, oculis caeruleis, pilo in contrarium verso, rictu ad aures dehiscente iuxta cornua mobilia. Tergori duritia silicis, omne respuens vulnus. Feras omnes venantur, ipsi non aliter quam foveis capti feritate semper intereunt.
english_text: but the fiercest wild bulls, the largest of the wild ones, speeding ahead of all, yellow in color, blue eyes, hair turned in the opposite direction, grinning to the ears beside the mobile horns. The hardness of the flint on the back, every repulsive wound. All wild beasts are hunted, and they are always killed by wildness, no differently than those caught in the pits.

Paragraph: Apud eosdem nasci Ctesias scribit quam mantichoran appellat, triplici dentium ordine pectinatim coeuntium, facie et auriculis hominis, oculis glaucis, colore sanguineo, corpore leonis, cauda scorpionis modo spicula infigentem, vocis ut si misceatur fistulae et tubae concentus, velocitatis magnae, humani corporis vel praecipue adpetentem.
english_text: Ctesias writes that he was born among them, whom he calls a manticore, with a triple row of comb-like teeth, a man's face and ears, gray eyes, the color of blood, the body of a lion, the tail of a scorpion striking like a spike, a voice as if it were a mixture of a flute and a concert of a trumpet, of great speed, of a human body or especially the one who gets it.

Paragraph: In India et boves solidis ungulis, unicornes, et feram nomine axin hinnulei pelle pluribus candidioribus que maculis, sacrorum Liberi patris (Orsaei Indi simias candentes toto corpore venantur), asperrimam autem feram monocerotem, reliquo corpore equo similem, capite cervo, pedibus elephanto, cauda apro, mugitu gravi, uno cornu nigro media fronte cubitorum duum eminente. hanc feram vivam negant capi.
english_text: In India there are also oxen with solid hooves, unicorns, and a beast called axin hinulei, with skin more white than spots, the sacred children of the Father (the Orsaean Indians hunt apes burning with their whole body), and the fiercest beast, the monocerote, the rest of the body resembling a horse, the head of a deer, the feet of an elephant, the tail a wild boar, with a heavy roar, with one black horn protruding two cubits from the middle of his forehead. they refuse to capture this living beast.

Paragraph: Apud Hesperios Aethiopas fons est Nigris, ut plerique existimavere, Nili caput, ut argumenta quae diximus persuadent. Iuxta hunc fera appellatur catoblepas, modica alioqui ceteris que membris iners, caput tantum praegrave aegre ferens (id deiectum semper in terram), alias internicio humani generis, omnibus, qui oculos eius videre, confestim expirantibus.
english_text: Among the Ethiopian Hesperians, the source of Nigris is, as most people think, the head of the Nile, as the evidence we have said convinces us. According to this beast is called a catoblepas, a little but inert in the rest of the limbs, bearing only the head with great pain (which is always thrown to the ground), otherwise the internalization of the human race, all who see its eyes, immediately expiring.

Paragraph: Eadem et basilisci serpentis est vis. Cyrenaica hunc generat provincia, duodecim non amplius digitorum magnitudine, candida in capite macula ut quodam diademate insignem. Sibilo omnes fugat serpentes nec flexu multiplici, ut reliquae, corpus inpellit, sed celsus et erectus in medio incedens. necat frutices, non contactos modo, verum et adflatos, exurit herbas, rumpit saxa: talis vis malo est. Creditum quondam ex equo occisum hasta et per eam subeunte vi non equitem modo, sed equum quoque absumptum.
english_text: The power is the same as that of the basilisk of the serpent. The province of Cyrenaica produces him, no more than twelve inches in size, with a white spot on his head like a sort of diadem. He drives away all the serpents with a hiss, and does not push the body with a multiplicity of bends, like the rest, but walks high and erect in the midst. it kills bushes, not only by contact, but also by blowing them, burns grass, breaks rocks: such force is evil. It is believed that once he was killed by a spear, and by the force of it, not only the horseman, but also the horse was taken away.

Paragraph: Atque huic tali monstro (saepe enim enectum concupivere reges videre) mustellarum virus exitio est: adeo naturae nihil placuit esse sine pare. Inferciunt has cavernis facile cognitis soli tabe. Necant illae simul odore moriuntur que, et naturae pugna conficitur.
english_text: And to such a monster (for kings are often enraged to see it) is the destruction of the virus of the weasels. They enter these caves easily recognized by the loss of the sun. Let them kill them at the same time they die of the smell, and the battle of nature is finished.

Paragraph: Sed in Italia quoque creditur luporum visus esse noxius vocem que homini, quem priores contemplentur, adimere ad praesens. Inertes hos parvos que Africa et Aegyptus gignunt, asperos truces que frigidior plaga. homines in lupos verti rursus que restitui sibi falsum esse confidenter existimare debemus aut credere omnia quae fabulosa tot saeculis conperimus. Vnde tamen ista vulgo infixa sit fama in tantum, ut in maledictis versipelles habeat, indicabitur.
english_text: But in Italy also it is believed that the sight of wolves is more harmful than the voice of a man, whose predecessors are contemplated. Inert these little ones that Africa and Egypt bring forth, rough and cruel than the coldest plague. we must confidently suppose that men turned into wolves again, that they are restored to themselves, is false, or believe all that we have found to be legendary for so many centuries. Whence, however, this popular reputation is so firmly planted, that it has lice in curses, will be told.

Paragraph: Euanthes, inter auctores Graeciae non spretus, scribit Arcadas tradere ex gente Anthi cuiusdam sorte familiae lectum ad stagnum quoddam regionis eius duci vestitu que in quercu suspenso tranare atque abire in deserta transfigurari que in lupum et cum ceteris eiusdem generis congregari per annos VIIII. Quo in tempore si homine se abstinuerit, reverti ad idem stagnum et, cum tranaverit, effigiem recipere, ad pristinum habitum addito novem annorum senio. Id quoque adicit, eandem recipere vestem.
english_text: Euanthes, who is not despised among the authors of Greece, writes that the Arcadas from the tribe of Anthi, a certain lot of the family, were laid to rest in a pool of a certain leader of that region, who was clothed in the clothes of a certain leader of that region, who was to swim in the suspended oak, and to go away into the desert, to be transformed into a wolf, and to gather together with the rest of the same kind for eighty-one years. At which time, if he had abstained from man, he should return to the same pond and, when he had swam, receive the effigy, adding to his former habit an old man of nine years. He also adds that he should receive the same garment.

Paragraph: Mirum est quo procedat Graeca credulitas! nullum tam inpudens mendacium est, ut teste careat. Item Apollas, qui Olympionicas scripsit, narrat Demaenetum Parrhasium in sacrificio, quod Arcades Iovi Lycaeo humana etiamtum hostia faciebant, immolati pueri exta degustasse et in lupum se convertisse, eundem X anno restitutum athleticae se exercuisse in pugilatu victorem que Olympia reversum.
english_text: It is strange how Greek credulity proceeds! There is no lie so shameless as to lack a witness. Likewise, Apollos, who wrote the Olympianica, relates that Demaenetus Parrhasius, at the sacrifice which the Arcades made to Jupiter Lycaeus as human victims, tasted the flesh of the sacrificed child and turned into a wolf, and that, having returned to Olympias in 10 years, he trained in boxing as a victor.

Paragraph: Quin et caudae huius animalis creditur vulgo inesse amatorium virus exiguo in villo eum que, cum capiatur, abici nec idem pollere nisi viventi dereptum. Dies, quibus coeat, toto anno non amplius duodecim. Eundem in fame vesci terra inter auguria; ad dexteram commeantium praeciso itinere si pleno id ore fecerit, nullum ominum praestantius.
english_text: Moreover, the tail of this animal is commonly believed to contain a little love virus in the village, which, when it is caught, is thrown away, and the same pollinator is not stolen unless it is alive. The days on which it meets are not more than twelve in the whole year. The same in the famine I ate the earth among the omens; to the right of those who travel by a precise route, if he does so with his full mouth, there is no better omen.

Paragraph: Sunt in eo genere qui cervari vocantur, qualem e Gallia in Pompei Magni harena spectatum diximus. Huic quamvis in fame mandenti, si respexerit, oblivionem cibi subrepere aiunt digressum que quaerere aliud.
english_text: They belong to that class which are called stags, such as we have seen seen in Gaul in the sand of Pompeii the Great. To him, although he is eating in hunger, if he looks back, they say that he has forgotten to sneak away food, rather than to look for something else.

Paragraph: Quod ad serpentes attinet, vulgatum est colorem eius pleras que terrae habere, in qua occultentur. Innumera esse genera. Cerastis corpore eminere cornicula saepe quadrigemina, quorum motu, reliquo corpore occulto, sollicitent ad se aves. Geminum caput amphisbaenae, hoc est et a cauda, tamquam parum esset uno ore fundi venenum. Aliis squamas esse, aliis picturas, omnibus exitiale virus. Iaculum ex arborum ramis vibrari, nec pedibus tantum pavendas serpentes, sed ut missile volare tormento. Colla aspidum intumescere, nullo ictus remedio praeterquam si confestim partes contactae amputentur.
english_text: As for serpents, it is common knowledge that most of them have the same color as the earth in which they hide. There are innumerable kinds. The hornbills often stand out from the body of the waxen quadrupeds, by whose movement the birds, with the rest of the body hidden, urge the birds towards them. The twin head of an amphisbaena, that is, from the tail, as if there were little poison in one mouth of the ground. For some it is scales, for others pictures, for all it is a deadly virus. To shake an arrow from the branches of trees, and not only to feed snakes with the feet, but to fly like a missile from a cannon. The neck of the asp becomes swollen, and there is no cure for the blow unless the parts in contact are immediately amputated.

Paragraph: Vnus huic tam pestifero animali sensus vel potius affectus est: coniugia ferme vagantur, nec nisi cum pari vita est. Itaque alterutra interempta incredibilis ultionis alteri cura: persequitur interfectorem unum que eum in quantolibet populi agmine notitia quadam infestat, perrumpit omnes difficultates, permeat spatia nec nisi amnibus arcetur aut praeceleri fuga.
english_text: There is one sense, or rather affection, of such a pestilent animal: the couple roams about closely, and life is only with equals. And so, each having been slain by an incredible desire of vengeance for the other, he pursues the one murderer who infests him with some information in every column of the people, breaks through all difficulties, penetrates the spaces, and only is driven away by rivers or by rapid flight.

Paragraph: Non est fateri rerum natura largius mala an remedia genuerit. Iam primum hebetes oculos huic malo dedit, eos que non in fronte adversos cernere, sed in temporibus (itaque excitatur saepius auditu quam visu), deinde internecivum bellum cum ichneumone.
english_text: It is not to be admitted that the nature of things has produced more generous evils or remedies. Now first he gave dull eyes to this evil, those who could not see their adversaries in front, but in times (and thus he is more often awakened by hearing than by sight), then the internecine war with the ichneumon.

Paragraph: Notum est animal hac gloria maxime, in eadem natum Aegypto. Mergit se limo saepius siccat que sole, mox ubi pluribus eodem modo se coriis loricavit, in dimicationem pergit. In ea caudam attollens ictus inritos aversus excipit, donec obliquo capite speculatus invadat in fauces. Nec hoc contentus aliud haud mitius debellat animal.
english_text: The animal known to this glory was especially born in Egypt. He sinks into the mud and dries himself more often than in the sun, and soon after he has girded himself with several skins in the same manner, he continues into battle. In it, raising its tail, it repels unrepentant blows, until, with a tilted head, it invades the throat. Nor, contented with this, did the animal beat down anything else any more mildly.

Paragraph: Crocodilum habet Nilus, quadripes malum et terra pariter ac flumine infestum. Vnum hoc animal terrestre linguae usu caret, unum superiore mobili maxilla inprimit morsum, alias terribile pectinatim stipante se dentium serie. Magnitudine excedit plerumque duodeviginti cubita. Parit ova quanta anseres, ea que extra eum locum semper incubat praedivinatione quadam, ad quem summo auctu eo anno egressurus est Nilus. nec aliud animal ex minore origine in maiorem crescit magnitudinem. Et unguibus autem armatus est, contra omnes ictus cute invicta. Dies in terra agit, noctes in aqua, teporis utrumque ratione.
english_text: The Nile has a crocodile, a four-footed evil, and the land is as hostile as the river. One of these terrestrial animals lacks the use of a tongue, one presses down the bite with its upper movable jaw, and at other times packs itself in a terrible comb-like series of teeth. It usually exceeds eighteen yards in size. It lays eggs as large as geese, which it always incubates outside that place, with a certain foresight, to which the Nile is about to rise at its greatest height that year. nor does any other animal grow from a smaller origin to a greater size. And he is armed with claws, his skin invincible against all blows. He spends the day on the land, the nights in the water, and the warmth of both.

Paragraph: Hunc saturum cibo piscium et semper esculento ore in litore somno datum parva avis, quae trochilos ibi vocatur, rex avium in Italia, invitat ad hiandum pabuli sui gratia, os primum eius adsultim repurgans, mox dentes et intus fauces quoque ad hanc scabendi dulcedinem quam maxime hiantes, in qua voluptate somno pressum conspicatus ichneumon, per easdem fauces ut telum aliquod inmissus, erodit alvum.
english_text: This little bird, given to sleep on the shore with its fill of fish-meat and its ever-nourishing mouth, which is there called trochilos, the king of birds in Italy, invites it to eat its food for its own sake, first cleaning its mouth with salt, and soon its teeth and inside its throat also, to this scratching sweetness as much as possible. gaping, in which pleasure the ichneumon, having seen the pressure of sleep, thrust through the same mouth as a weapon, erodes the intestine.

Paragraph: Similis crocodilo, sed minor etiam ichneumone, est in Nilo natus scincos, contra venena praecipuus antidotis, item ad inflammandam virorum venerem. Verum in crocodilo maior erat pestis quam ut uno esset eius hoste natura contenta. Itaque et delphini inmeantes Nilo, quorum dorso tamquam ad hunc usum cultellata inest pinna, abigentes eos praedam ac velut in suo tantum amne regnantes, alioqui inpares viribus ipsi, astu interimunt. Callent enim in hoc cuncta animalia sciunt que non sua modo commoda, verum et hostium adversa, norunt sua tela, norunt occasiones partes que dissidentium inbelles. In ventre mollis est tenuis que cutis crocodilo: ideo se ut territi mergunt delphini subeuntes que alvum illa secant spina.
english_text: Similar to the crocodile, but even smaller than the ichneumon, there is a skink born in the Nile, the chief antidote against poisons, and also for the inflammation of venereal men. It is true that the crocodile was a greater pest than that nature was content with one of its enemies. And so the dolphins entering the Nile, whose backs have a fin like a knife for this purpose, drive them away for prey and as if reigning only in their own river, otherwise they are unequal to their own strength, and they kill them by cunning. For all animals are wise in this, they know that they are not comfortable in their own way, and that they are hostile to their enemies; The belly is as soft as the skin of a crocodile: therefore the dolphins drown themselves as if terrified, when they undergo that thorn cut their bowels.

Paragraph: Quin et gens hominum est huic beluae adversa in ipso Nilo, a Tentyri insula, in qua habitat, appellata. Mensura eorum parva, sed praesentia animi in hoc tantum usu mira. Terribilis haec contra fugaces belua est, fugax contra sequentes.

Paragraph: Tarandro magnitudo quae bovi est, caput maius cervino nec absimile, cornua ramosa, ungulae bifidae, villus magnitudine ursorum, sed, cum libuit sui coloris esse, asini similis. Tergori tanta duritia, ut thoraces ex eo faciant. colorem omnium arborum, fruticum, florum locorum que reddit metuens in quibus latet, ideoque raro capitur. Mirum esset habitum corpori tam multiplicem dari, mirabilius est et villo.
english_text: A deer the size of an ox, a head larger than a deer and not dissimilar, with ramified horns, cloven hooves, a hair the size of a bear, but, when it pleased to be of its own color, it resembled an ass. The back is so hard that they make chests out of it. fearing the color of all the trees, bushes, and flowers of the places in which he hides, he is seldom caught. It would be a wonderful habit to give the body so many things, and it is even more wonderful for a village.

Paragraph: Hystrices generat India et Africa, spinea contectas cute irenaceorum genere, sed hystrici longiores aculei et, cum intendit cutem, missiles. ora urgentium figit canum et paulo longius iaculatur. Hibernis autem se mensibus condit, quae natura multis et ante omnia ursis.
english_text: Porcupines are native to India and Africa, with spines covered by the skin of the genus Irenaceae, but porcupines have longer spines and, when they pierce the skin, missiles. the mouth of the dog is fixed and shot a little farther. But the Hibernians store themselves for months, which is the nature of many and above all bears.

Paragraph: Eorum coitus hiemis initio nec vulgari quadripedum more, sed ambobus cubantibus conplexis que; dein secessus in specus separatim, in quibus pariunt XXX die plurimum quinos. Hi sunt candida informis que caro, paulo muribus maior, sine oculis, sine pilo; ungues tantum prominent. Hanc lambendo paulatim figurant. Nec quicquam rarius quam parientem videre ursam. Ideo mares quadragenis diebus latent, feminae quaternis mensibus.
english_text: Their mating in the winter was not at first in the common quadrupedal fashion, but with both of them entwined lying down; then they retire to caves separately, in which they give birth to a large number of quinos in 30 days. These are white in shape like flesh, a little larger than mice, without eyes or hair; the nails only stick out. By licking this little by little they shape it. Nor is anything rarer than to see a bear giving birth. That is why males lie dormant for forty days, females for four months.

Paragraph: Specus si non habuere, ramorum fruticum que congerie aedificant, inpenetrabiles imbribus molli que fronde constratos. Primis diebus bis septenis tam gravi somno premuntur, ut ne vulneribus quidem excitari queant. tunc mirum in modum veterno pinguescunt. Illi sunt adipes medicaminibus apti contra que defluvium capilli tenaces. Ab his diebus residunt ac priorum pedum suctu vivunt. Fetus rigentes adprimendo pectori fovent non alio incubitu quam ad ova volucres.
english_text: If they did not have caves, they build a heap of bushy branches, impenetrable by the rains, covered with soft leaves. In the first days of two weeks they are pressed into such a deep sleep that they cannot even be awakened by their wounds. then they become strangely fat in the old fashion. They are the fats that are suitable for cosmetics that prevent hair loss. From these days they remain, and live by the suction of their former feet. By pressing the frozen fetuses to the breast, they shelter them in no other place than the eggs of birds.

Paragraph: Mirum dictu, credit Theophrastus per id tempus coctas quoque ursorum carnes, si adserventur, increscere; cibi nulla tunc argumenta nec nisi umoris minimum in alvo inveniri, sanguinis exiguas circa corda tantum guttas, reliquo corpori nihil inesse.
english_text: Strange to say, Theophrastus believes that during that time the flesh of bears cooked also, if they are kept, will grow; then there was no evidence of food, and only the slightest moisture was to be found in the stomach, only a few drops of blood around the heart, and nothing in the rest of the body.

Paragraph: Procedunt vere, sed mares praepingues, cuius rei causa non prompta est, quippe ne somno quidem saginatis, praeter XIIII dies, ut diximus. Exeuntes herbam quandam arum nomine laxandis intestinis, alioqui concretis, devorant friant que surculos dentibus praedomantes ora. Oculi eorum hebetantur, qua maxime causa favos expetunt, ut convulneratum ab apibus os levet sanguine gravedinem illam.
english_text: They do indeed proceed, but the males are very fat, the reason for which is not readily apparent, since they are not even stuffed with sleep, except for fourteen days, as we have said. Going out, they devour a kind of herb called arum, which relaxes the bowels, or in other words congeals, and eats the shoots which they devour with their teeth. Their eyes are dull, for which reason they seek the honeycombs, so that the mouth wounded by the bees may relieve the burden of blood.

Paragraph: Invalidissimum urso caput, quod leoni firmissimum. Ideo urgente vi praecipitaturi se ex aliqua rupe manibus cooperto iaciuntur ac saepe in harena colapho infracto exanimantur. Cerebro veneficium inesse Hispaniae credunt occisorum que in spectaculis capita cremant testato, quoniam potum in ursinam rabiem agat. Ingrediuntur et bipedes; arborem aversi derepunt.
english_text: The weakest head of a bear, the strongest of a lion. Therefore, with urgent force, they throw themselves down from some rock with their hands covered, and often die in the sand when broken by the blow. The Spaniards believe that the brain is poisoned by those who have been killed, and they burn their heads in spectacles, as a witness, because the drink makes the bear mad. They also enter bipeds; They crawled up the tree.

Paragraph: Tauros ex ore cornibus que eorum omnibus pedibus suspensi pondere fatigant. Nec alteri animalium in maleficio stultitia sollertior. Annalibus notatum est M. Pisone M. Messala cos. a. d. XIIII kal. Oct. Domitium Ahenobarbum aedilem curulem ursos Numidicos centum et totidem venatores Aethiopas in circo dedisse. Miror adiectum Numidicos fuisse, cum in Africa ursum non gigni constet.
english_text: Bulls wear their horns from their mouths with the weight suspended by all their feet. Nor is the folly more skillful in evil than any other animal. In the annals it is noted that M. Piso M. Messala cos. a. d. 14 cal. Oct. Domitius Ahenobarbus, the aedic curule, had given a hundred Numidian bears and the same number of Ethiopian hunters in the circus. I wonder if the Numidians were added, since it is clear that the bear did not breed in Africa.

Paragraph: Conduntur hieme et Pontici mures, dumtaxat albi, quorum palatum in gustu sagacissimum auctores quonam modo intellexerint miror. conduntur et Alpini, quibus magnitudo melium est, sed hi pabulo ante in specus convecto, cum quidem narrant alternos marem ac feminam subrosae conplexos fascem herbae supinos, cauda mordicus adprehensa, invicem detrahi ad specum ideoque illo tempore detrito esse dorso. Sunt his pares et in Aegypto similiter que resident in clunes et binis pedibus gradiuntur prioribus que ut manibus utuntur.
english_text: Pontic mice are also eaten in the winter, but only white ones, whose palate is so discerning in taste that I wonder how the authors understood it. The Alpines are also hired, whose size is better than the honey, but these are first brought to the cave with fodder, when indeed they say that alternately the male and the female, entwined with a bundle of sub-rose grass on their backs, with their biting tails seized, dragged each other to the cave, and therefore at that time their backs were crushed. They are equal to these, and likewise in Egypt, who sit on their backs, and walk with two feet before the former, who use them as hands.

Paragraph: Praeparant hiemi et irenacei cibos ac volutati supra iacentia poma adfixa spinis, unum amplius tenentes ore, portant in cavas arbores. Iidem mutationem aquilonis in austrum condentes se in cubile praesagiunt. Vbi vero sensere venantem, contracto ore pedibus que ac parte omni inferiore, qua raram et innocuam habent lanuginem, convolvuntur in formam pilae, ne quid conprehendi possit praeter aculeos.
english_text: They prepare food for the winter and the Irenaeus, and, rolling over the apples lying on top of the thorns, and holding one more in their mouths, they carry them into the hollows of the trees. They foretell the change of the north into the south, placing themselves in bed. But when they feel that they are hunting, they close their mouths with their feet, and on their lower part, where they have a rare and harmless down, they roll themselves up in the form of a ball, so that nothing can be caught but the stings.

Paragraph: In desperatione vero urinam in se reddunt tabificam, tergori suo spinis que noxiam, propter hoc se capi gnari. Quam ob rem exinanita prius urina venari ars est, et tum praecipua dos tergori, alias corrupto, fragili, putribus spinis atque deciduis, etiam si vivat subtractus fuga. Ob id non nisi in novissima spe maleficio eo perfunditur, quippe et ipsi odere suum veneficium, ita parcentes sibi terminum que supremum opperientes, ut ferme ante captivitas occupet. Calidae postea aquae adspersu resolvitur pila, adprehensus que pes alter e posterioribus suspendiosa fame necat. Aliter non est occidere et tergori parcere.
english_text: But in desperation they put urine into themselves, which is poisonous, and which is harmful to their spines, because of this they know that they will be caught. For this reason, it is the art of hunting the urine first emptied, and then the main gift of the hind, otherwise corrupted, fragile, with rotten spines and deciduous, even if it lives with a withdrawn flight. For this reason only in the last hope is he imbued with evil, seeing that even they themselves hate their own witchcraft, thus sparing themselves the limit which is the last, that it may take hold before captivity. The ball is then dissolved by the sprinkling of warm water. It is not otherwise to kill and spare the rear.

Paragraph: Ipsum animal non, ut remur plerique, vitae hominum supervacuum est, si non sint illi aculei, frustra vellerum mollitia in pecude mortalibus data: hac cute expoliuntur vestes. Magnum fraus et ibi lucrum monopolio invenit, de nulla re crebrioribus senatus consultis nullo que non principe adito querimoniis provincialibus.
english_text: The animal itself is not, as most people think, unnecessary to the life of men, if it were not for those thorns, they would in vain want the softness given to mortal cattle: with this skin the clothes are refined. A great fraud, and there he found a profit by monopoly, on no subject more frequently consulted by the senate than by any other than the chief, who appealed to the provincial complaints.

Paragraph: Vrinae et duobus aliis animalibus ratio mira. Leontophonon accipimus vocari parvum nec aliubi nascens quam ubi leo gignitur, quo gustato tanta illa vis et ceteris quadripedum imperitans ilico expiret. Ergo corpus eius exustum adspergunt aliis carnibus polentae modo insidiantes ferae necant que etiam cinere: tam contraria est pestis.
english_text: Vrina and two other animals have a wonderful account. We take Leontophonon to be called a small one, born nowhere else than where a lion is born, and when he has tasted that great strength and is ignorant of other quadrupeds, he immediately expires. Therefore they sprinkle his burnt body with other meats, in the manner of wild beasts lying in wait, and kill them also with ashes: it is so contrary to the pestilence.

Paragraph: Haut inmerito igitur odit leo visum que frangit et citra morsum exanimat; ille contra urinam spargit, prudens hanc quoque leoni exitialem.
english_text: Therefore he undeservedly hates the sight of the lion, which breaks him and suffocates him with his bite; he sprinkles against the urine, knowing that this too is fatal to the lion.

Paragraph: Lyncum umor ita redditus, ubi gignuntur, glaciatur arescit vein gemmas carbunculis similes et igneo colore fulgentes, lyncurium vocatas atque ob id sucino a plerisque ita generari prodito. Novere hoc sciunt que lynces et invidentes urinam terra operiunt, eoque celerius solidatur illa.
english_text: The moisture of the lynx being thus restored, where they are born, freezes and dries up the veins, which resemble carbuncles and shine with a fiery color, called lyncurium, and because of this the sucinus is betrayed by most people to be so born. They know that lynxes and those who hate it cover the earth with urine, and the more quickly it solidifies.

Paragraph: Alia sollertia in metu melibus: sufflatae cutis distentu ictus hominum et morsus canum arcent. Provident tempestatem et sciuri obturatis que, qua spiraturus est ventus, cavernis ex alia parte aperiunt fores. De cetero ipsis villosior cauda pro tegumento est. Ergo in hiemes aliis provisum pabulum, aliis pro cibo somnus.
english_text: Another skill in the fear of honeybees: they ward off the blows of men and the bites of dogs by stretching out their blown skin. They provide for the storm and the squirrels are blocked, so that when the wind is about to blow, they open the doors of the caves from the other side. Of the rest, the hairy tail is for a covering. Therefore in the winter fodder was provided for others, and sleep for others.

Paragraph: Serpentium vipera sola terra dicitur condi, ceterae arborum aut saxorum cavis. Et alias vel annua fame durant, algore modo dempto. Omnia secessus tempore veneno orba dormiunt. Simili modo et cocleae, illae quidem iterum et aestatibus, adhaerentes maxime saxis aut, etiam iniuria resupinatae avolsae que, non tamen exeuntes.
english_text: Snakes and vipers are said to be found only in the ground, the others in the hollows of trees or rocks. And at other times they endure even annual famines, when they are only fed with food. At the time of retirement all the worlds sleep with poison. In like manner also the snails, indeed again and in the summers, clinging to most rocks or, even injured, recumbent and torn off, which, however, do not come out.

Paragraph: In Baliaribus vero insulis cavaticae appellatae non prorepunt e cavis terrae (neque herba vivunt), sed uvae modo inter se cohaerent. est et aliud genus minus vulgare adhaerente operculo eiusdem testae se operiens. Obrutae terra semper hae et circa maritimas tantum Alpes quondam effossae coepere iam erui et in Veliterno. omnium tamen laudatissimae in Astypalaea insula.
english_text: But in the Balearic Islands, the so-called cavats, do not crawl out of the hollows of the earth (nor do they live on grass), but the grapes are only attached to each other. there is also another species less vulgar, adhering to the cover of the same shell. The ruins of the land are always here, and only around the coast the Alps, once excavated, have already begun to be excavated, and in Veliterno. but the most praised of all was in the island of Astypalaea.

Paragraph: Lacertae, inimicissimum genus cocleis, negantur semenstrem vitam excedere. Lacerti Arabiae cubitales, in Indiae vero Nyso monte XXIIII in longitudinem pedum, colore fulvi aut punicei aut caerulei.
english_text: Lizards, the most hostile species of snails, are denied to leave their half-life. The lizards of Arabia are cubits long, and in India, on Mount Nysus, 241 feet in length, and of a yellow, pink, or blue color.

Paragraph: Ex his quoque animalibus, quae nobis cum degunt, multa sunt cognitu digna, fidelissimum que ante omnia homini canis atque equus. pugnasse adversus latrones canem pro domino accepimus confectum que plagis a corpore non recessisse, volucres ac feras abigentem. Ab alio in Epiro agnitum in conventu percussorem domini laniatu que et latratu coactum fateri scelus. Garamantum regem canes CC ab exilio reduxere proeliati contra resistentes. Propter bella Colophonii itemque Castabalenses cohortes canum habuere.
english_text: Of these animals also, which live with us, there are many worthy of knowledge, the dog and the horse being the most faithful of all to man. that he had fought against the robbers, we took for his master a dog that had not withdrawn from his body with wounds, and was driving away birds and beasts. By another in Epirus, he was recognized in the assembly as the master's assailant, who was forced to confess the crime by beating him and barking. 200 dogs brought back King Garamantus from exile and fought against the resisters. Because of the wars of Colophonius and also of Castabales, the cohorts had dogs.

Paragraph: Hae primae dimicabant in acie numquam detrectantes; haec erant fidissima auxilia nec stipendiorum indiga. Canes defendere Cimbris caesis domus eorum plaustris inpositas. Canis Iasone Lycio interfecto cibum capere noluit inedia que consumptus est. Is vero, cui nomen Hyrcani reddit Duris, accenso regis Lysimachi rogo iniecit se flammae, similiter que Hieronis regis.
english_text: These were the first to fight in the battle line, never retreating; these were the most reliable helpers and did not need wages. The dogs that the Cimbri killed to defend their houses were placed in carts. When the dog Jason Lycius was killed, he refused to take food because he was consumed by hunger. But he, to whom Duris gives the name of Hyrcanus, having been fired at the request of King Lysimachus, threw himself into the flames, in the same way as King Hieron.

Paragraph: Memorat et Pyrrhum, Gelonis tyranni canem, Philistus; memoratur et Nicomedis Bithyniae regis, uxore eius Cosingi lacerata propter lasciviorem cum marito iocum. Apud nos Vulcatium nobilem, qui Cascellium ius civile docuit, asturcone e suburbano redeuntem, cum advesperavisset, canis a grassatore defendit; item Caelium senatorem aegrum Placentiae ab armatis oppressum, nec prius ille vulneratus est quam cane interempto.
english_text: He also mentions Pyrrhus, the dog of the tyrant Gelonus, a Philistine; It is also mentioned that Nicomedes, king of Bithynia, was torn by his wife Cosinga because of her lascivious play with her husband. Among us, the nobleman Vulcatius, who taught the civil law of Cascelli, returning from the suburbs with an asturcon, when he had spent the evening, was defended by a dog from a raider; likewise Caelius, the sick senator of Placentia, was crushed by the armed men, and he was not wounded before he was killed by a dog.

Paragraph: Sed super omnia in nostro aevo actis p. R. testatum Appio Iunio et P. Silio cos., cum animadverteretur ex causa Neronis Germanici filii in Titium Sabinum et servitia eius, unius ex his canem nec in carcere abigi potuisse nec a corpore recessisse abiecti, in gradibus gemitoriis maestos edentem ululatus magna populi Romani corona, ex qua cum quidam ei cibum obiecisset, ad os defuncti tulisse. Innatavit idem, cadavere in Tiberim abiecto, sustentare conatus, effusa multitudine ad spectandam animalis fidem.
english_text: But above all that has been done in our age, p. R. testified to Appius Junius and P. Silius cos., when it was observed that on account of Nero's son Germanicus in Titius Sabinus and his servants, the dog of one of these could neither be driven away in prison nor removed from his body, while eating mournfully on the steps of the tombs, the great howl of the Roman people the wreath, from which, when some one had offered him food, he had brought it to the mouth of the deceased. He floated the same, after the corpse had been thrown into the Tiber, and tried to support it, while the multitude poured out to watch the animal's faith.

Paragraph: Soli dominum novere et ignotum quoque, si repente veniat, intellegunt; soli nomina sua, soli vocem domesticam agnoscunt. Itinera quamvis longa meminere, nec ulli praeter hominem memoria maior. Impetus eorum et saevitia mitigatur ab homine considente humi.
english_text: They understand that they only know the master, and also the unknown, if he should come suddenly; they recognize only their own names, only the domestic voice. The journey, however long, is remembered, and no man's memory is greater than that of man. Their attack and ferocity is moderated by a man sitting on the ground.

Paragraph: Plurima alia in iis cotidie vita invenit, sed in venatu sollertia et sagacitas praecipua est. Scrutatur vestigia atque persequitur, comitantem ad feram inquisitorem loro trahens, qua visa quam silens et occulte, set quam significans demonstratio est cauda primum, deinde rostro! Ergo etiam senecta fessos caecos que ac debiles sinu ferunt, ventos et odorem captantes protendentes que rostra ad cubilia.
english_text: Every day life finds many other things in them, but in hunting skill and sagacity are most important. He scrutinizes the tracks and pursues them, drawing his companion to the wild investigator with a lure, which he saw how silent and secret, but how significant a demonstration is the tail first, then the snout! Therefore, even the old, tired, blind men, who carry the weak in their bosoms, catching the winds and the smell, stretching out their noses to the beds.

Paragraph: E tigribus eos Indi volunt concipi et ob id in silvis coitus tempore alligant feminas. Primo et secundo fetu nimis feroces putant gigni, tertio demum educant. Hoc idem e lupis Galli, quorum greges suum quisque ductorem e canibus et ducem habent. Illum in venatu comitantur, illi parent; namque inter se exercent etiam magisteria.
english_text: The Indians want to conceive them from tigers, and for this reason they bind the women in the forests at the time of mating. They think that the first and second litters are too fierce to breed, and finally they bring up the third. The same is the case with the Gauls, whose flocks each have their own leader of dogs and a leader. They accompany him in the hunt, they take care of him; for they also exercise mastery among themselves.

Paragraph: (Certum est iuxta Nilum amnem currentes lambere, ne crocodilorum aviditati occasionem praebeant) Indiam petenti Alexandro Magno rex Albaniae dono dederat inusitatae magnitudinis unum, cuius specie delectatus iussit ursos, mox apros et deinde dammas emitti, contemptim inmobili iacente eo, qua segnitia tanti corporis offensus imperator generosi spiritus interemi eum iussit. nuntiavit hoc fama regi. Itaque alterum mittens addidit mandata, ne in parvis experiri vellet, sed in leone elephantove: duos sibi fuisse, hoc interempto praeterea nullum fore.
english_text: (It is certain that those who run along the river Nile should lick, lest they give occasion to the greed of the crocodiles.) Alexander the Great, king of Albania, had given a gift of unusual size to the claimant of India. The emperor, with a noble spirit, ordered him to be killed. He told this report to the king. Accordingly, sending another, he added instructions that he would not try with small ones, but with a lion or an elephant;

Paragraph: Nec distulit Alexander leonem que fractum protinus vidit. Postea elephantum iussit induci, haut alio magis spectaculo laetatus. Horrentibus quippe villis per totum corpus ingenti primum latratu intonuit, mox ingruit adsultans contra que membra exurgens hinc et illinc artifici dimicatione, qua maxime opus esset, infestans atque evitans, donec adsidua rotatum vertigine adflixit, ad casum eius tellure concussa.
english_text: Nor did Alexander put off the lion, which he immediately saw broken. Afterwards he ordered the elephant to be brought in, being more pleased with another spectacle. For he first roared with a terrible bark through the whole body of the huge one, and soon rushed forward against him, raising his limbs here and there in a skirmish, which was most necessary, attacking and evading, until he was afflicted with constant vertigo, shaken to his fall by the earth.

Paragraph: Canum generi bis anno partus. iusta ad pariendum annua aetas. Gerunt uterum sexagenis diebus. Gignunt caecos et, quo largiore aluntur lacte, eo tardiorem visum accipiunt, non tamen umquam ultra XXI diem nec ante septimum. Quidam tradunt, si unus gignatur, nono die cernere, si gemini, decumo itemque in singulos adici totidem tarditatis ad lucem dies, et ab ea quae sit femina ex primipara genita Faunos cerni. optimus in fetu qui novissimus cernere incipit aut quem primum fert in cubile feta.
english_text: Dogs breed twice a year. just to give birth annually. They bear the womb for sixty days. They are born blind, and the more abundantly they are fed with milk, the slower they receive their sight, but never beyond the 21st day, nor before the seventh. Some say that, if one is born, it is seen on the ninth day, if it is twins, on the tenth, and likewise to each one is added the same number of days of slowness to the light, and by that which is a woman from the first-born, the Faunus is seen. the best of the offspring is the one who is the last to begin to see, or the first to carry the fetus to bed.

Paragraph: Rabies canum sirio ardente homini pestifera, ut diximus, ita morsis letali aquae metu. Quapropter obviam itur per XXX eos dies, gallinaceo maxime fimo inmixto canum cibis aut, si praevenerit morbus, veratro. A morsu vero unicum remedium, oraculo quodam nuper repertum, radix silvestris rosae, quae cynorrhoda appellatur.
english_text: As we have said, the rabies of a dog is a pestilential disease of a burning dog, so that the bite of the water is fatal. For this reason he goes to meet them for 30 days, mainly with chicken dung mixed with dog food or, if the disease occurs, with veratro. But the only remedy for a bite, which a certain oracle has recently discovered, is the root of the wild rose, which is called rosy rhododendron.

Paragraph: Columella auctor est, si XL die quam sit natus castretur morsu cauda summus que eius articulus auferatur spinae nervo exempto, nec caudam crescere nec canes rabidos fieri. Canem locutum in prodigiis, quod equidem adnotaverim, accepimus et serpentem latrasse, cum pulsus Tarquinius est regno.
english_text: Columella is the authority that if on the 40th day after he is born he is castrated by biting the top of his tail, that his joint is taken away free of the spinal cord, and neither the tail will grow nor the dogs become rabid. The dog that spoke in prodigies, which indeed I had recorded, we also received that the serpent barked when Tarquinius was in the kingdom.

Paragraph: Eidem Alexandro et equi magna raritas contigit. Bucephalan eum vocarunt sive ab aspectu torvo sive ab insigni taurini capitis armo inpressi. XIII talentis ferunt ex Philonici Pharsalii grege emptum, etiam tum puero capto eius decore. Neminem hic alium quam Alexandrum regio instratu ornatus recepit in sedem, alias passim recipiens.
english_text: A great rarity happened to the same Alexander and the horse. They called him Bucephalan, either because of his grim look or because of his striking bull-headed armor. They say that he was bought from the herd of Philonicus of Pharsalius for 13 talents, and that he was also captured as a boy for his beauty. He received no one else here than Alexander, decked out in the royal robes, and receiving others here and there.

Paragraph: Idem in proeliis memoratae cuiusdam perhibetur operae, Thebarum oppugnatione vulneratus in alium transire Alexandrum non passus, multa praeterea eiusdem modi, propter quae rex defuncto ei duxit exequias urbem que tumulo circumdedit nomine eius.
english_text: The same is said of the deeds of a certain man in the battles which have been mentioned. Alexander, wounded by the attack of the Thebans, did not suffer himself to cross over to another.

Paragraph: Nec Caesaris dictatoris quemquam alium recepisse dorso equus traditur, idemque similes humanis pedes priores habuisse, hac effigie locatus ante Veneris Genetricis aedem. Fecit et Divus Augustus equo tumulum, de quo Germanici Caesaris carmen est. Agrigenti conplurium equorum tumuli pyramides habent. Equum adamatum a Samiramide usque in coitum Iuba auctor est.
english_text: Nor is it reported that the dictator Caesar received any other horse on his back, and that the same former had human-like feet. Divus Augustus also built the mound on horseback, about which there is a poem by Germanicus Caesar. In Agrigento several horse mounds have pyramids. He is the author of the diamond horse from Samiramide to the marriage of Juba.

Paragraph: Scythici quidem equitatus equorum gloria strepunt: occiso regulo ex provocatione dimicante hostem, cum ad spoliandum venisset, ab equo eius ictibus morsu que confectum; alium detracto oculorum operimento et cognito cum matre coitu petiisse praerupta atque exanimatum. aequa ex causa in Reatino agro laceratum prorigam invenimus. Namque et cognationum intellectus his est, atque in grege prioris anni sororem libentius etiam quam matrem equa comitatur.
english_text: Indeed, the cavalry of the Scythians make a noise of the glory of their horses: when the king was slain by provocation, fighting the enemy, when he had come to plunder, he was finished off by the blows of his horse; another, having taken off her blindfold, and having known that she had sought intercourse with her mother, she was taken aback and breathless. For a fair reason we find a torn proriga in the field of Reatinus. For he also has an understanding of kinship with these, and in the herd of the previous year he accompanies his sister even more willingly than his mother mare.

Paragraph: Docilitas tanta est, ut universus Sybaritani exercitus equitatus ad symphoniae cantum saltatione quadam moveri solitus inveniatur. Iidem praesagiunt pugnam et amissos lugent dominos: lacrimas interdum desiderio fundunt. interfecto Nicomede rege equus eius inedia vitam finivit.
english_text: The docility is so great, that the whole cavalry of the Sybaritan army is wont to move with a sort of dance to the music of the symphony. They foretell the battle and mourn the loss of their lords: sometimes they shed tears of longing. When King Nicomedes was killed, his horse died of starvation.

Paragraph: Phylarchus refert Centaretum e Galatis, in proelio occiso Antiocho, potitum equo eius conscendisse ovantem, at illum indignatione accensum domitis frenis, ne regi posset, praecipitem in abrupta isse exanimatum que una. Philistus a Dionysio relictum in caeno haerentem, ut se evellisset, secutum vestigia domini examine apium iubae inhaerente, eo que ostento tyrannidem a Dionysio occupatam.
english_text: Phylarchus reports that Centaretus of Galatia, having slain Antiochus in the battle, having taken possession of his horse, was shouting, but having indignantly set him on the bridle, so that he could not be controlled, he fell headlong into the precipice and died alone. The Philistine, left by Dionysius, stuck in the mud, as if he had pulled himself up, followed in the footsteps of his master, examining the bees clinging to his mane, by which I showed the tyranny seized by Dionysius.

Paragraph: Ingenia eorum inenarrabilia. Iaculantes obsequia experiuntur difficiles conatus corpore ipso nisu que iuvantium; item tela humi collecta equiti porrigunt. nam in circo ad currus iuncti non dubie intellectum adhortationis et gloriae fatentur.
english_text: Their talents are indescribable. Those who throw obedience experience difficult efforts with the body by the same effort as those who help them; also the weapons collected on the ground are handed to the horsemen. for in the circus they are bound to the chariots, they admit without doubt of the understanding of encouragement and glory.

Paragraph: Claudi Caesaris saecularium ludorum circensibus, excusso in carceribus auriga albati Corace, occupavere primatum, optinuere opponentes, effundentes omnia que contra aemulos, quae debuissent peritissimo auriga insistente, facientes, cum puderet hominum artes ab equis vinci, peracto legitimo cursu ad cretam stetere.
english_text: At Claudius Caesar's secular circuses of games, the white charioteer Corace, shaken in the prisons, desirous of seizing the primacy, desirous of opposing them, pouring out all that they should have done against their rivals, which they ought to have insisted upon by the most skilful charioteer, doing, when they were ashamed of the skill of men to be overcome by the horses, having finished their legitimate course, stood at the chalk.

Paragraph: Maius augurium apud priscos plebeis circensibus excusso auriga ita, ut si staret, in Capitolium cucurrisse equos aedem que ter lustrasse; maximum vero eodem pervenisse a Veis cum palma et corona, effuso Ratumenna qui ibi vicerat, unde postea nomen portae est.
english_text: A greater augury among the ancient plebeian circuses was that the charioteer was shaken so that, if he stood still, he ran into the Capitol and inspected the house three times; but the greatest one arrived at the same time from the Veis with palm and crown, shed by Ratumenna, who had conquered there, whence afterwards the name of the gate.

Paragraph: Sarmatae longinquo itineri inedia pridie praeparant eos, potum exiguum inpertientes, atque ita per centena milia et quinquaginta continuo cursu euntibus insident. Vivunt annis quidam quinquagenis, feminae minore spatio; eaedem quinquennio finem crescendi capiunt, mares anno addito. Forma equorum, quales maxime legi oporteat, pulcherrime quidem Vergilio vate absoluta est; sed et nos diximus in libro de iaculatione equestri condito, et fere inter omnes constare video. Diversa autem circo ratio quaeritur. Itaque cum bimi in alio subiungantur imperio, non ante quinquennes ibi certamen accipit.
english_text: The Sarmatians prepare them the day before for the hunger of a long journey, by supplying them with a little drink, and so they set out by a hundred and fifty thousand marching at a rapid pace. Some live to the age of fifty years, the women for a shorter period; In the same five years they take the end of growing, the males an additional year. Paragraph: Partum in eo genere undenis mensibus ferunt, duodecimo gignunt. coitus verno aequinoctio bimo utrimque vulgaris, sed a trimatu firmior partus. Generat mas ad annos XXXIII, utpote cum a circo post vicesimum annum mittantur ad subolem. Opunte et ad XL durasse tradunt adiutum modo in attollenda priore parte corporis.

Paragraph: Sed ad generandum paucis animalium minor fertilitas. Qua de causa intervalla admissurae dantur, nec tamen quindecim initus eiusdem anni valet tolerare. equarum libido extinguitur iuba tonsa. Gignunt annis omnibus ad quadragesimum. Vixisse equum LXXV annos proditur.
english_text: But to breed a few animals, the fertility is lower. For this reason intervals of interbreeding are given, and yet fifteen entries of the same year cannot be tolerated. the lust of mares is extinguished by a shorn mane. They give birth every year to the fortieth year. The horse is said to have lived 75 years.

Paragraph: In hoc genere gravida stans parit praeter que ceteras fetum diligit. Et sane equis amoris innasci veneficium, hippomanes appellatum, in fronte, caricae magnitudine, colore nigro, quod statim edito partu devorat feta aut partum ad ubera non admittit. Si quis praereptum habeat, olfactu in rabiem id genus agitur. Amissa parente in grege armenti reliquae fetae educant orbum. Terram attingere ore triduo proximo quam sit genitus negant posse. Quo quis acrior, in bibendo nares mergit. Scythae per bella feminis uti malunt, quoniam urinam cursu non inpedito reddant.
english_text: In this race, standing pregnant, he gives birth, besides he loves other fetuses. And of course, horses are born with a poison of love, called hippomanes, in the forehead, the size of a carica, and of a black color, which devours the fetus as soon as it is born, or does not admit the birth to the udder. If a person has a seizure, that kind of treatment is carried out by smelling it into rabies. Having lost its parent in the herd, the rest of the offspring raise the world. They deny that he can touch the earth with his mouth three days after he is born. When someone is more active, he sinks his nose in drinking. The Scythians prefer to use women during wars, because they can urinate without difficulty.

Paragraph: Constat in Lusitania circa Olisiponem oppidum et Tagum amnem equas favonio flante obversas animalem concipere spiritum, id que partum fieri et gigni pernicissimum ita, sed triennium vitae non excedere. In eadem Hispania Gallaica gens est et Asturica; equini generis his sunt quos tieldones vocamus; minore forma appellatos asturcones gignunt, quibus non vulgaris in cursu gradus, sed mollis alterno crurum explicatu glomeratio, unde equis tolutim carpere incursum traditur arte. Equo fere qui homini morbi, praeter que vesicae conversio, sicut omnibus in genere veterino.
english_text: It is established in Lusitania, near the town of Olisipone and the river Tagus, that mares are blown over with a fawn to conceive an animal spirit, which gives birth and the birth is most destructive in this way, but does not exceed three years of life. In the same Spain there is a Gallic nation and an Asturian; These are of the equine race, which we call tieldons; in a smaller form they give birth to the so-called asturcones, which do not have a common step in running, but a soft, alternately unfolded grouping of the legs, from which the trotting horse is taught the art of taking a charge. In the horse almost all the diseases in man, except that the conversion of the bladder, as in all in the old race.

Paragraph: Asinum CCCC nummum emptum Q. Axio senatori auctor est M. An animal most impatient of cold. therefore it is not born in Pontus, nor is it admitted at the vernal equinox, like other cattle, but at the solstice.

Paragraph: Mares in remissione operis deteriores. Partus a tricensimo mense ocissimus, sed a trimatu legitimus, totidem quot equae et isdem mensibus et simili modo. Sed incontinens uterus urina genitale reddit, ni cogatur in cursum verberibus a coitu. raro geminos parit. Paritura lucem fugit et tenebras quaerit, ne conspiciatur ab homine. Gignit tota vita, quae est ei ad tricensimum annum.

Childbirth from the thirtieth month is very fatal, but from the third month it is legitimate, as many mares and in the same months and in a similar manner. But the incontinent uterus produces genital urine, lest it be forced into the course by the blows of intercourse. rarely gives birth to twins. Childbirth flees from the light and seeks the darkness, so as not to be seen by man. He gives birth to all his life, which is to his thirtieth year.

Paragraph: Partus caritas summa, sed aquarum taedium maius: per ignes ad fetus tendunt, eaedem, si rivus minimus intersit, horrent etiam pedes omnino tinguere. nec nisi adsuetos potant fontes quae sunt in pecuariis, atque ita ut sicco tramite ad potum eant. Nec pontes transeunt per raritatem eorum tralucentibus fluviis, mirum que dictu, sitiunt et si mutentur aquae; ut bibant cogendae exorandae vesunt. Nec nisi spatiosa in cubitu laxitas tuta; varia namque somnio visa concipiunt ictu pedum crebro, qui nisi per inane emicuit, repulsu durioris materiae clauditatem ilico adfert.
english_text: Childbirth is a great charity, but the weariness of the waters is greater: they tend to the children through fires, and if the slightest stream intervenes, they are afraid to completely drench their feet. nor can they drink unless they are accustomed to the fountains which are in the cattle-yards, and so that they go to drink by a dry path. Nor do bridges pass through their rarity in the transparent rivers; as they were forced to drink Nor is it safe to relax spaciously in the elbow; for they conceive the various things seen in a dream by the frequent stroke of the feet, which, if it did not flash through the void, immediately brings on the lameness by the repulsion of the harder material.

Paragraph: Quaestus ex iis opima praedia exuperat. Notum est in Celtiberia singulas quadringentena milia nummum enixas, mularum maxime partu. Aurium referre in iis et palpebrarum pilos aiunt; quamvis enim unicolori reliquo corpore, totidem tamen colores, quot ibi fuere, reddi. Pullos earum epulari Maecenas instituit, multum eo tempore praelatos onagris. Post eum interiit auctoritas saporis asino. (Moriente visu celerrime id genus deficit.)
english_text: The profit from them had taken away rich estates. It is known that in Celtiberia each four hundred thousand coins were cast, chiefly by the birth of mules. They say that the ear and the hairs of the eyelids are in them; for although the rest of the body was of one color, yet as many colors were returned as were there. Maecenas established that their chickens should be feasted on, much preferred at that time to onagers. After him died the authority of the taste of the ass. (Dying sight quickly fails that sort of thing.)

Paragraph: Ex asino et equa mula gignitur mense XIII, animal viribus in labores eximium. Ad tales partus equas neque quadrimis minores neque decennibus maiores legunt arceri que utrumque genus ab altero narrant nisi in infantia eius generis quod ineat lacte hausto. Quapropter subreptos pullos in tenebris equarum uberi asinarum veeculeos admovent. Gignitur autem mula et ex equo et asina, sed effrenis et tarditatis indomitae. Lenta omnia et e vetulis.
english_text: A mule is born from an ass and a mare in the 13th month, an animal of extraordinary strength for labor. For such births they read that mares neither four months younger nor ten years older should be kept away, that they tell each kind from the other, except in the infancy of that kind which enters into milk. For this reason, in the dark, they move the stolen foals to the udders of the mares. Now the mule is born from both a horse and an ass, but it is untamed and slow. Everything is tough and old.

Paragraph: Conceptum ex equo secutus asini coitus abortu perimit, non item asini equus. Feminas a partu optime septimo die inpleri observatum, mares fatigatos melius inplere. Quae non prius, quam dentes quos pullinos appellant iaciat, conceperit, sterilis intellegitur et quae non primo initu generare coeperit. equo et asina genitos mares hinnulos antiqui vocabant contra que mulos quos asini et equae generarent.
english_text: A conception from a horse, followed by intercourse with an ass, perishes by abortion, but not also the horse of the ass. It is observed that females are best filled from birth on the seventh day, males are better filled when they are tired. A woman who has not conceived before she casts her teeth, which are called pullets, is understood to be barren, and she who has not begun to procreate at the first entry. In ancient times, males born to horses and donkeys were called fowls, as opposed to mules born to donkeys and mares.

Paragraph: Observatum ex duobus diversis generibus nata tertii generis fieri et neutri parentium esse similia ea que ipsa, quae sunt ita nata, non gignere in omni animalium genere; idcirco mulas non parere. est in annalibus nostris peperisse saepe, verum prodigii loco habitum. Theophrastus vulgo parere in Cappadocia tradit, sed esse id animal ibi sui generis.
english_text: It is observed that those born of two different kinds become of a third kind, and that neither parent is like that which itself, which is thus born, does not beget in any kind of animals; therefore the mules did not breed. it is in our annals that it has often given birth, but the truth has been held in the place of a prodigy. Theophrastus reports that it is commonly bred in Cappadocia, but that it is an animal of its own kind there.

Paragraph: Mulae calcitratus inhibetur vini crebriore potu. In plurium Graecorum est monumentis cum equa muli coitu natum quod vocaverint ginnum, id est parvum mulum. Generantur ex equa et onagris mansuefactis mulae veloces in cursu, duritia eximia pedum, verum strigoso corpore, indomito animo. sed generator onagro et asina genitus omnes antecellit. Onagri in Phrygia et Lycaonia praecipui. Pullis eorum ceu praestantibus sapore Africa gloriatur, quos lalisiones appellat.
english_text: The kicking of the mule is checked by frequent drinking of wine. In the records of many Greeks, he was born from the union with a mare of a mule, which they called a ginnus, that is, a small mule. Mules are born from tame mares and onagers, swift in their running, with extraordinary hardness of feet, but with a strong body, and an indomitable spirit. but the one born on an onager and the one born on an ass excels them all. Onagris chief in Phrygia and Lycaonia. Africa boasts of their chickens, or of their excellent taste, which they call lalisions.

Paragraph: Mulum LXXX annis vixisse Atheniensium monimentis apparet; gavisi namque, cum templum in arce facerent, quod derelictus senecta scandentia iumenta comitatu nisu que exhortaretur, decretum fecere ne frumentarii negotiatores ab incerniculis eum arcerent.
english_text: It appears from the monuments of the Athenians that the mule lived 80 years; for when they were building a temple in the citadel, which had been abandoned by an old man who was driven by a company of climbing cattle, they were glad to make a decree that the grain-dealers should not drive him away from the fields.

Paragraph: Bubus Indicis camelorum altitudo traditur, cornua in latitudinem quaternorum pedum. In nostro orbe Epiroticis laus maxima a Pyrrhi, ut ferunt, iam inde regis cura. Id consecutus est non ante quadrimatum ad partus vocando; praegrandes itaque fuere et hodie que reliquiae stirpium durant. At nunc anniculae fecunditatem poscuntur, tolerantius tamen bimae, tauri generationem quadrimi. Inplent singuli denas eodem anno. tradunt, si a coitu in dexteram partem abeant tauri, generatos mares esse; si in laevam, feminas.
english_text: An Indian ox is said to be the height of a camel, with horns four feet wide. In our country, the highest praise of the Epirotics, as they say, from Pyrrhus, is now the concern of the king. This he obtained, not before four months, by calling for delivery; They must therefore have been very great even to this day, and the remnants of the race last. But now the fecundity of the yearlings is demanded, yet more tolerant of the bima, the fourth generation of the bull. Each one fills the dens in the same year. they say that if the bulls go to the right side from the mating, they are born males; if to the left, women.

Paragraph: Conceptio uno initu peragitur, quae si forte pererravit, XX post diem marem femina repetit. pariunt mense X; quicquid ante genitum, inutile est. Paragraph: Non degeneres existimandi etiam minus laudato aspectu: plurimum lactis Alpinis, quibus minimum corporis, plurimum laboris capite, non cervice, iunctis. Syriacis non sunt palearia, sed gibber in dorso. Tauris minora quam bubus cornua tenuiora que.

The Caricians, too, in the part of Asia, are said to be excellent in their work, with a hideous appearance of a lump protruding from their necks on their arms, with dislodged horns, but otherwise black and white, or condemned to labor. Bulls have smaller horns than oxen.

Paragraph: Domitura boum in trimatu, postea sera, ante praematura. Optime cum domito iuvencus inbuitur. Socium enim laboris agri que culturae habemus hoc animal, tantae apud priores curae, ut sit inter exempla damnatus a populo Romano die dicta, qui concubino procaci rure omassum edisse se negante occiderat bovem, actus que in exilium tamquam colono suo interempto.
english_text: Taming of the oxen in the early season, later late, before early. It is best drunk with a tamed youngster. For this animal, the companion of the labor of the land which we cultivate, was so much cared for by the former, that it was among the examples of those condemned by the Roman people in the day, who had killed an ox while denying that he had eaten the meat of his impertinent concubine.

Paragraph: Tauris in aspectu generositas torva fronte, auribus saetosis, cornibus in procinctu dimicationem poscentibus. Sed tota comminatio prioribus in pedibus. Stat ira gliscente alternos replicans spargens que in alvum harenam et solus animalium eo stimulo ardescens.

A nation of Thessalians was found to kill bulls with a horse beside a quadrupedal horn with a twisted neck; Caesar, the dictator of Rome, was the first to give that spectacle.

Paragraph: Hinc victimae opimae et lautissima deorum placatio. Huic tantum animali omnium, quibus procerior, cauda non statim nato consummatae ut ceteris mensurae: crescit uni, donec ad vestigia ima perveniat. quam ob rem victimarum probatio in vitulo, ut articulum suffraginis contingat; breviore non litant. Paragraph: Bos in Aegypto etiam numinis vice colitur; Apin vocant. Insigne ei in dextro latere candicans macula cornibus lunae crescere incipientis, nodus sub lingua, quem cantharum appellant. Non est fas eum certos vitae excedere annos, mersum que in sacerdotum fonte necant quaesituri luctu alium, quem substituant, et donec invenerint maerent derasis etiam capitibus; nec tamen umquam diu quaeritur.

It is not right that he should go beyond the certain years of his life, drowned in the fountain of the priests, who will seek in mourning another to replace him, and until they find him, they will mourn, even with their heads shaved; and yet it is never asked for long.

Paragraph: Inventus deducitur Memphin a sacerdotibus C. delubra ei gemina, quae vocant thalamos, auguria populorum: alterum intrasse laetum est, in altero dira portendit. Responsa privatis dat e manu consulentium cibum capiendo. Germanici Caesaris manum aversatus est haut multo postea extincti. Cetero secretus, cum se proripuit in coetus, incedit submotu lictorum, greges que puerorum comitantur carmen honori eius canentium; intellegere videtur et adorari velle. Hi greges repente lymphati futura praecinunt.

Paragraph: Sunt et in hac parte naturae auguria, sunt et piscibus praescita. Siculo bello ambulante in litore Augusto piscis e mari ad pedes eius exilivit, quo argumento vates respondere, Neptunum patrem adoptante tum sibi Sexto Pompeio tanta erat navalis rei gloria, sub pedibus Caesaris futuros qui maria tempore illo tenerent.
english_text: There are omens in this part of nature, and they are also predicted by fishes. In the Sicilian war, when Augustus was walking on the shore, a fish leaped out of the sea at his feet, to which argument the sailors answered, that having adopted Neptune as his father and Sextus Pompey for himself, such was the naval glory of the matter, that under Caesar's feet those who would hold the seas at that time were to come.

english_text: Gaius Marius, in his second consulship, properly dedicated it to the Roman legions. and formerly she was the first, with four others: the wolves, the minotaurs, the horses, and the boars, each in front of the ranks. a few years before she had begun to be carried alone into the army, the rest being left in the camp; Marius renounced them altogether. from which it is noted, that there is hardly ever a winter camp of a legion where there is not a yoke of eagles.

Paragraph: Celebris apud Seston urbem aquilae gloria es<t>: educ<a>tam a virgine retulisse gratiam aves primo, mox deinde venatus adgerentem, defuncta postremo in rogum accensum eius iniecisse sese et simul conflagrasse. quam ob causam incolae quod vocant heroum in eo loco fecere, appellatum Iovis et Virginis, quoniam illi deo ales adscribitur.
english_text: You are famous in the city of Sesto for the glory of the eagle: it was taught by the virgin that the birds first returned the favor, then immediately hunted them down, and finally, when they were dead, they threw themselves into the burning pyre and at the same time burst into flames. for which reason the inhabitants make what they call a hero in that place, called Jupiter and the Virgin, since wings are ascribed to that god.

english_text: We find sixteen kinds of hawks, of which the hawk, lame on the other foot, is a very successful augury for marriage affairs and livestock matters; triorche<m> from the number of witnesses, to whom he gave the leadership in the omens of Phemonoe. but the Romans call this one, also known as a family, because he sat in the captain's ship with a favorable auspices.
