Paragraph: In Thraciae parte super Amphipolim homines et accipitres societate quadam aucupantur. hi ex silvis et harundinetis excitant aves, illi supervolantes deprimunt rursus; captas aucupes dividunt cum <i>is. traditum est missas in sublime sibi excipere eos et, cum sit tempus capturae, clangore ac volatus genere invitare ad occasionem. simile quiddam lupi ad Maeotim paludem faciunt. nam nisi partem a piscantibus suam accepere, expansa eorum retia lacerant.
english_text: On the Thracian side, above Amphipolis, men and hawks hunt in a certain company. these raise the birds from the woods and reeds; they divide the captured fowls with them. it is traditional to welcome them in masses on high, and, when it is time for the draft, to invite them to the occasion with clangs and flights. The wolves do something similar in the Maeotis marsh. for if they did not receive their share from the fishermen, they would tear open their nets.

Paragraph: Accipitres avium non edunt corda. nocturnus accipiter cybindis vocatur, rarus etiam in silvis, interdiu minus cernens. bellum internecivum gerit cum aquila, cohaerentesque saepe prenduntur.
english_text: Hawks do not eat the hearts of birds. it is called a nocturnal hawk, rare even in the woods, seeing less during the day. he carries on an internecine war with the eagle, and the confederates are often captured.

Paragraph: Coccyx videtur ex accipitre fieri, tempore anni figuram mutans, quoniam tunc non apparent reliqui nisi perquam paucis diebus. ipse quoque, modico tempore aestatis visus, non cernitur postea. est autem neque aduncis unguibus, solus accipitrum, nec capite similis illis neque alio quam colore, ac visu columbi potius; quin et absumitur ab accipitre, si quando una apparuere, sola omnium avis a suo genere interempta.

Paragraph: Proxime gloriam sentiunt et hi nostri vigiles nocturni, quos excitandis in opera mortalibus rumpendoque somno natura genuit. norunt sidera et ternas distinguunt horas interdiu cantu. cum sole eunt cubitum quartaque castrensi vigilia ad curas laboremque revocant nec solis ortum incautis patiuntur obrepere diemque venientem nuntiant cantu, ipsum vero cantum plausu laterum.
english_text: These our night watchmen, whom nature has begotten by awakening them from mortal labors and breaking their sleep, feel a close sense of glory. they know the stars and trines and distinguish the hours of the day by song. they go to bed with the sun, and at the fourth watch of the camp they call back to their cares and labors, and do not suffer the rising of the sun to sneak up unwary, and announce the coming day with a song, but the song itself with the clapping of the wings.

english_text: Caecina Volaterranus of the cavalry order, the master of the teams, taking the captives with him to the city, sent the news of the victory to his friends, who were returning to the same nest covered with the colors of victory. And Fabius Pictor, in his annals, reports that when the Roman garrison was besieged by the Ligustini, a swallow was brought to him by the chickens, tied to its feet with knots of linen, to indicate on what day the eruption should take place on the arrival of help.

english_text: the eggs of birds are brittle from heat, those of snakes are soft from cold, and fish are soft from liquid. the water tank is round, the rest is almost topped with a pinnacle. they issue from the roundest part of themselves, while they are born, with a soft skin, but immediately hardening in whatever portions they emerge. Horatius Flaccus thinks that the oblong eggs have a more agreeable taste. they eat the female which is born rounder, the rest the male. the umbilical cord of the sheep is from the top, or a drop protruding from the butt.

Paragraph: Quaedam omni tempore coeunt, ut gallinae, et pariunt, praeterquam duobus mensibus hiemis brumalibus. ex iis iuvencae plura quam veteres, sed minora, et in eodem fetu prima ac novissima. est autem tanta fecunditas, ut aliquae et sexagena pariant, aliquae cotidie, aliquae bis die, aliquae in tantum, ut effetae moriantur. Hadrianis laus maxima.
english_text: Some come together at all times, like hens, and give birth, except during the two winter months. of these the heifers are more numerous than the old ones, but smaller, and the first and the last are in the same litter. but the fecundity is so great, that some give birth to sixty children, some every day, some twice a day, some only so much that they die in effect. Hadrian's greatest praise.

Paragraph: columbae deciens anno pariunt, quaedam et undeciens, in Aegypto vero etiam brumali mense. hirundines et merulae et palumbi et turtures bis anno pariunt, ceterae aves fere semel. turdi, in cacuminibus arborum luto nidificantes paene contextim, in secessu generant. a coitu X diebus ova maturescunt in utero, vexatis autem gallinae et columbae pinna evulsa aliave simili iniuria diutius.
english_text: Doves give birth ten times a year, and some even eleven, and in Egypt even in the winter month. swallows and blackbirds and pigeons and turtles give birth twice a year, other birds about once. the thrushes, nesting in the mud of the tops of the trees, almost woven together, breed in retirement. 10 days after copulation, the eggs mature in the womb, but longer when a hen and a dove have been harassed by having their fin pulled out or some other similar injury.

Paragraph: Omnibus ovis medio vitelli parva inest velut sanguinea gutta, quod esse cor avium existimant, primum in omni corpore id gigni opinantes: in ovo certe gutta ea salit palpitatque. ipsum animal ex albo liquore ovi corporatur. cibus eius in luteo est. omnibus intus caput maius toto corpore, oculi conpressi capite maiores. increscente pullo candor in medium vertitur, luteum circumfunditur.
english_text: In every egg there is a small drop of blood in the middle of the yolk, which they think is the heart of birds, thinking that it is the first thing in every body that is born. the animal itself is made up of the white liquid of the egg. His food is in yellow. all inside the head is larger than the whole body, the eyes are compressed and larger than the head. As the chicken grows, the whiteness is turned in the middle, and the yellow is poured around.

Paragraph: vicensimo die si moveatur ovum, iam viventis intra putamen vox auditur. ab eodem tempore plumescit, ita positus, ut caput supra dextrum pedem habeat, dextram vero alam supra caput. vitellus paulatim deficit. aves omnes in pedes nascuntur, contra quam reliqua animalia.
english_text: on the twentieth day, if the egg is moved, the voice of the already living one is heard inside the shell. from the same time he becomes feathered, so placed that his head is above his right foot, and his right wing above his head. the yolk gradually declines. All birds are born on feet, unlike other animals.

Paragraph: quaedam gallinae omnia gemina ova pariunt et geminos interdum excludunt, ut Cornelius Celsus auctor est, alterum maiorem; aliqui negant omnino geminos excludi. plus vicena quina incubanda subici vetant. parere a bruma incipiunt. optima fetura ante vernum aequinoctium. post solstitium nata non implent magnitudinem iustam tantoque minus, quanto serius provenere.
english_text: some hens lay all twin eggs, and sometimes hatch the twins, as Cornelius Celsus is the author of, the second larger; some deny that twins are excluded at all. more than twenty which they forbid to be subjected to incubation. they begin to bear the bruma. best breeding before the spring equinox. those born after the solstice do not fill their proper size, and so much less, the later they come.

Paragraph: Ova incubari intra decem dies edita utilissimum; vetera aut recentiora infecunda. subici inpari numero debent. quarto die post quam coepere incubari, si contra lumen cacumine ovorum adprehenso ima manu purus et unius modi perluceat color, sterilia existimantur esse proque <i>is alia substituenda. et in aqua est experimentum: inane fluitat, itaque sidentia, hoc est plena, subici volunt. concuti vero experimento vetant, quoniam non gignant confusis vitalibus venis.
english_text: Eggs hatched within ten days are most useful; old or more recent infertile. they must be submitted in an odd number. on the fourth day after the beginning of incubation, if against the light the top of the eggs, held by the lower hand, shows a pure and transparent color, they are considered to be sterile, and another must be substituted for them. and there is a test in the water: it floats empty, so they want to be put to rest, that is full. but they forbid them to be shaken by trial, because they do not give birth when their vital veins are confused.

Paragraph: incubationi datur initium post novam lunam, quia prius inchoata non proveniant. celerius excluduntur calidis diebus; ideo aestate undevicensimo educent fetum, hieme XXV. si incubitu tonuit, ova pereunt; et accipitris audita voce vitiantur. remedium contra tonitrus clavus ferreus sub stramin<e> ovorum positus aut terra ex aratro.
english_text: the incubation is given a beginning after the new moon, because those that have begun earlier do not come out. they are more quickly excluded on hot days; therefore in the summer they bring forth the offspring in the nineteenth, in the winter the twenty-fifth. if it thunders while lying down, the eggs perish; and at the sound of the hawks, they shall perish. A remedy against thunder is an iron nail placed under a straw of eggs, or earth from the plough.

Paragraph: quaedam autem et citra incubitum sponte natura<e> gignunt, ut in Aegypti fimetis. scitum de quodam potore reperitur Syracusis tam diu potare solitum, donec cooperta terra fetum edere<nt> ova.
english_text: and some, even on this side of the lying-in, naturally bring forth naturally, as in Egypt the dung beetle. it is known of a certain drinker, it is found in Syracuse that it was customary to drink so long, until the ground was covered, that the fetus would eat the eggs.

Paragraph: Quin et ab homine perficiuntur. Iulia Augusta prima sua iuventa Tib. Caesare ex Nerone gravida, cum parere virilem sexum admodum cuperet, hoc usa est puellari augurio, ovum in sinu fovendo atque, cum deponendum haberet, nutrici per sinum tradendo, ne intermitteretur tepor; nec falso augurata proditur. nuper inde fortassis inventum, ut ova calido in loco inposita paleis igne modico foverentur homine versante, pariterque et stato die illinc erumperet fetus.
english_text: Moreover, they are also completed by man. Julia Augusta in her early youth Tib. When Caesar was pregnant by Nero, when she was very desirous of giving birth to the male sex, she used this as an augury for a girl, by nurturing the egg in her bosom and, when it was about to be deposited, handing it over to the nurse through her bosom, so that the heat might not be interrupted; nor is it falsely prophesied. It was recently discovered, perhaps, that the eggs, placed in a warm place with straw, were warmed by a small fire while the man was turning, and at the same time the fetus broke out on the other side.

Paragraph: traditur quaedam ars gallinarii cuiusdam dicentis, quod ex quaque esset. narrantur et mortua gallina mariti earum visi succedentes in vicem et reliqua fetae more facientes abstinentesque se cantu. super omnia est anatum ovis subditis atque exclusis admiratio prima non plane agnoscentis fetum, mox incerti sin<g>ultus sollicite convocantis, postremo lamenta circa piscinae stagna mergentibus se pullis natura duce.
english_text: a certain art of poultry-keeping is handed down, of a certain saying, that it was from each one. It is said that the dead hens were seen succeeding their husbands in turn, and the rest of the fowls doing their custom and refraining from singing. Above all there is the wonder of the duck at the tame and shut out of the ewes, at first not quite recognizing the fetus, then the uncertain cackling of the anxiously summoning them, and lastly the wailing of the ducklings drowning around the pools of the pool.

Paragraph: Gallinarum generositas spectatur crista erecta, interim et gemina, pinnis nigris, ore rubicundo, digitis inparibus, aliquando et super IIII digitos traverso uno. ad rem divinam luteo rostro pedibusque purae non videntur, ad opertanea sacra nigrae. est et pumilionum genus non sterile in <i>is, quod non in alio genere alitum, sed quibus centra, fecunditas rara et incubatio ovis noxia.
english_text: The breed of hens is seen with an erect crest, meanwhile, and twins, with black feathers, a red beak, unequal toes, and sometimes over 4 toes across one. they do not seem pure to the divine thing with their yellow beaks and feet; and there is a genus of dwarfs not sterile in them, which are not fed in another genus, but in which centers, the fecundity is rare, and the incubation of the eggs is harmful.

Paragraph: Inimicissima autem omni generi pituita maximeque inter messis ac vindemiae tempus. medicina in fame et cubitus in fumo, utique si e lauru aut herba sabina fiat, pinna per traversas inserta nares et per omnes dies mota; cibus alium cum farre aut aqua perfusus, in qua maduerit noctua, aut cum semine vitis albae coctus ac quaedam alia.
english_text: But the slime is most hostile to all kinds, and especially between the time of harvest and vintage. medicine in hunger and elbows in smoke, of course if it is made of laurel or sabina grass, a fin inserted through the crossbars of the nose and moved all day long; other food with mash, or steeped in water, in which nightshade has ripened, or cooked with the seed of the white vine, and other things.

Paragraph: Columbae proprio ritu osculantur ante coitum. pariunt fere bina ova, ita natura moderante, ut aliis crebrior sit fetus, aliis numerosior. palumbis et turtur plurimum terna nec plus quam bis vere pariunt, atque ita, si prior fetus corruptus est et <ut>, quamvis III pepererint, numquam plus II educant. tertium inritum est; urinum vocant. palumbis incubat femina post meridiana in matutinum, cetero mas.
english_text: Doves kiss before mating in their own ritual. they give birth to about two eggs, in such a way that nature controls, so that for some the brood is more frequent, for others more numerous. Pigeons and turtles, for the most part, do not give birth more than twice in the spring, and so, if the first brood is corrupted and <so> that, although they have given birth to 3, they never bring up more than 2. the third is unwritten; they call it urine. The female incubates the pigeons after noon into the morning, and the male in the rest.

Paragraph: columbae marem semper et feminam pariunt, priorem marem, postridie feminam. incubant in eo genere ambo, interdiu mas, noctu femina. excludunt XX die, pariunt a coitu V. aestate quidem interdum binis mensibus terna educunt paria, namque XVIII die excludunt statimque concipiunt; quare inter pullos s<a>epe ova inveniuntur, et alii provolant, alii erumpunt. ipsi deinde pulli quinquemenstres fetificant.
english_text: Doves always give birth to a male and a female, the former a male, the next day a female. Both incubate in that genus, the male during the day, the female at night. they hatch on the 20th day, they give birth from mating on the 5th. In the summer, indeed, sometimes they bring out three pairs in two months, for they hatch on the 18th day and immediately conceive; therefore eggs are often found among the chickens, and some hatch, others burst. then the five-month-old chicks themselves are fattened.

Paragraph: et ipsae autem inter se, si mas non sit, feminae aeque saliunt pariuntque ova inrita, ex quibus nihil gignitur, quae hypenemia Graeci vocant.
english_text: and among themselves, if there is no male, the females jump together and give birth to unripe eggs, from which nothing is born, which the Greeks call hypenemia.

Paragraph: Pavo a trimatu parit; primo anno unum aut alterum ovum, sequenti quaterna quinave, ceteris duodena, non amplius, intermittens binos dies ternosve parit, et ter anno, si gallinis subiciantur incubanda. mares ea frangunt desiderio incubantium; quapropter noctu et in latebris pariunt aut in excelso cubantes, <s>et nisi molli strato excepta franguntur. mares singuli quinis sufficiunt coniugibus. cum singulae aut binae fuere, corrumpitur salacitate fecunditas. partus excluditur diebus ter novenis aut tardius tricensimo.
english_text: A peacock gives birth to a trimmed one; in the first year she lays one or two eggs, in the following four to fifteen, in the rest twelve, no more, with intervals of two or three days, and three times a year, if hens are subjected to incubation. the males break them with the desire of the brooding; therefore they give birth at night and in hiding, or lying on a high ground, and are broken unless they are excepted on a soft bed. males alone are sufficient for couples. when there are one or two, fertility is spoiled by salinity. delivery is excluded on the third ninth day or later on the thirtieth day.

Paragraph: Anseres in aqua coeunt, pariunt vere aut, si bruma coiere, post solstitium, XL prope, bis anno, si priorem fetum gallinae excludant, alia<s> plurima ova XVI, paucissima VII. si quis subripiat, pariunt donec rumpantur. aliena non excludunt.
english_text: Geese mate in the water, they give birth in the spring, or, if it is winter, after the solstice, nearly 40, twice a year, if they hatch the previous brood of hens, the most eggs are 16, the fewest 7. if someone steals, they breed until they are broken. they do not exclude others.

Paragraph: incubanda subici utilissimum VIIII aut XI. incubant feminae tantum tricenis diebus, si vero tepidior<e>s sint, XXV. pullis eorum urtica contactu mortifera, nec minus aviditas nunc satietate nimia, nunc suamet vi, quando adprehensa radice morsu saepe conantes avellere ante colla sua abrumpunt. contra urticam remedium est stramento ab incubitu subdita radix earum.
english_text: to incubate the most useful 8 or 11 females incubate only three hundred days, if they are warmer, 25. to their chicks the stinging nettle is deadly by contact, and not the less greedy, now with excessive satiety, now with their own force, when they are caught by the root and bite, often trying to tear it off before their necks. The remedy against nettles is the root of them covered with straw from lying down.

Paragraph: Ardiolarum tria genera: leucon, as<t>eria<s>, pelion. hi in coitu anguntur; mares quidem cum vociferatu sanguinem etiam ex oculis profundunt. nec minus aegre pariunt gravidae.
english_text: Three genera of Ardiola: leucon, as<t>eria<s>, pelion. these are distressed in intercourse; indeed, the males, when shouting, draw blood even from their eyes. nor do pregnant women give birth with less difficulty.

Paragraph: aquila tricenis diebus incubat et fere maiores alites, minores vicenis, ut miluus et accipiter. <m>ilu<u>s fere parit numquam plus ternos, is qui aego<li>os vocatur et quaternos, corvus aliquando et quinos. incubant totidem diebus. cornicem incubantem mas pascit. pica novenos, melancoryphus supra XX parit, semper numero inpari, nec alia i<is> plures: tanto fecunditas maior parvis. hirundini caeci primo pulli sunt et fere omnibus quibus numerosior fetus.
english_text: The eagle incubates for three hundred days, and usually the larger wings, the smaller twenty, like the hawk and the hawk. Ilu<u>s almost never gives birth to more than threes, that which is called aego<li>os and quaternos, a crow sometimes and quinos. they incubate for the same number of days. the male feeds the incubating cornice. the pica gives birth to nine, the melancoryphus gives birth to more than 20, always an odd number, and no other i<is> more: so great is the fecundity of the small. blind swallows are the first chicks, and almost all of them have more numerous offspring.

Paragraph: Inrita ova, quae hypenemia diximus, aut mutua feminae inter se libidinis imaginatione concipiunt aut pulvere, nec columbae tantum, sed et gallinae, perdices, pavones, anseres, chenalopeces. sunt autem sterilia et minora ac minus iucundi saporis et magis umida. quidam et vento putant ea generari, qua de causa etiam zephyria appellant. urina autem vere tantum fiunt incubatione derelicta, quae alii cynosura dixere.
english_text: The unripe eggs, which we have called hypenemia, are conceived either by the mutual imagination of women among themselves, or by dust; but they are sterile and smaller and less pleasant in taste and more moist. some also think that they are generated by the wind, for which reason they are also called zephyrs. but the urine is really only produced by abandoned incubation, which others say is a shame.

Paragraph: ova aceto macerata in tantum emolliuntur, ut per anulos transeant. servari ea in lomento aut hieme in paleis, aestate in furfuribus utilissimum. sale exinaniri creduntur.
english_text: eggs soaked in vinegar are softened to such an extent that they pass through the rings. it is most useful to keep them in the hay or in winter in straw, in summer in bran. They are believed to be emptied of salt.

Paragraph: Volucrum animal parit vespertilio tantum, cui et membranaceae pinnae uni. eadem sola volucrum lacte nutrit ubera admovens. parit geminos; volitat amplexa infantes secumque portat. eidem coxendi<x> una traditur e<sse>. in cibatu culices gratissimi.
english_text: A bird gives birth only to a bat, which has only one membranous fin. the same bird alone feeds with milk by moving its breasts. gives birth to twins; she flies and carries the children in her arms. The same coxing<x> is handed over to e<sse>. in the food of the favorite mosquitoes.

Paragraph: Rursus in terrestribus ova pariunt serpentes, de quibus nondum dictum <e>st. coeunt conplexu, adeo circumvolutae sibi ipsae, ut una existimari biceps possit. viperae mas caput inserit in os, quod illa abrodit voluptatis dulcedine.
english_text: Again, serpents give birth to terrestrial eggs, of which it has not yet been said. they come together in a complex, so wrapped around themselves that they can be thought of as one biceps. the male of the viper puts the head into his mouth, which it tears away with the sweetness of pleasure.

Paragraph: terrestrium eadem sola intra se parit ova, unius coloris et mollia, ut pisces. terti<o> die intra uterum catulos excludit, dein singulis diebus singulos parit, XX fere numero. itaque ceteri tarditatis inpatientes perrumpunt latera occisa parente. ceterae serpentes contexta ova in terra incubant et fetum sequenti excludunt anno. crocodili vicibus incubant, mas et femina. sed reliquorum quoque terrestrium reddatur generatio.
english_text: the same terrestrial one produces eggs within itself, of the same color and soft, like fish. on the third day she hatches the cubs within the womb, after which she gives birth each day, about 20 in number. and so the others, impatient of the delay, break through the flanks of the slain parent. other snakes incubate the woven eggs in the ground and hatch the fetus the following year. crocodiles incubate by turns, male and female. but the generation of the rest of the earth must also be returned.

Paragraph: Bipedum solus homo animal gignit. homini tantum primi coitus paenitentia, augurium scilicet vitae a paenitenda origine. ceteris animalibus stati per tempora anni concubitus, homini, ut dictum est, omnibus horis dierum noctiumque; ceteris sa<t>ias in coitu, homini prope nulla.
english_text: Man alone produces a bipedal animal. To man only the first intercourse is penitence, that is, the augury of life from the penitent origin. with the other animals standing during the seasons of the year, man, as has been said, at all hours of the day and of the night; for the rest of the sa<t>ias in intercourse, the man is almost none.

Paragraph: Messalina Claudi Caesaris coniunx, regalem hanc existimans palmam, elegit in id certamen nobilissimam e prostitutis ancillam merce<n>ariae stipis eamque nocte ac die superavit quinto atque vicensimo concubitu. in hominum genere maribus deverticula veneris, excogitata omnia scelere naturae, feminis vero abortus. quantum in hac parte multo nocentiores quam ferae sumus! viros avidiores veneris hieme, feminas aestate Hesiodus prodidit.
english_text: Messalina, the consort of Claudius Caesar, considering this a royal palm, chose for that contest the most noble of the prostitutes, a mercenary maid, and overcame her night and day with the fifth and twentieth intercourse. in the human race you come to men with deviance, everything conceived by the crime of nature, but to women abortion. how in this respect we are much more dangerous than wild animals! Hesiod betrayed the greedy men in the winter, the women in the summer.

Paragraph: Coitus aversis elephantis, camelis, tigribus, lyncibus, rhinoceroti, leoni, dasypodi, cuniculis, quibus aversa genitalia. cameli etiam solitudines aut secreta certe petunt, neque intervenire datur sine pernicie; coitus tot<o> die, et his tantum ex omnibus. quibus solida ungula in quadripedum genere, mares olfactus a<c>cendit. avertuntur et canes, phocae, lupi, in medioque coitu invitique etiam cohaerent.
english_text: Coitus turned away from elephants, camels, tigers, lynxes, rhinoceroses, lions, dasypods, rabbits, whose genitals are turned away. camels also certainly seek deserts or secrets, and it is not allowed to intervene without destruction; intercourse for so many days, and only these of all. with which solid hooves in the quadruped race, the males smelled. they are turned away, and dogs, seals, and wolves, and in the midst of intercourse, even reluctantly join together.

Paragraph: supra dictorum <dasypodum> plerumque feminae priores superveniunt, in reliquis mares. ursi autem, ut dictum est, humanitus strati, irenacei stantes ambo inter se conplexi, feles mare stante, femina subiacente, vulpes in latera proiectae maremque femina amplexa. taurorum cervorumque feminae vim non tolerant; ea de causa ingrediuntur in conceptu. cervi vicissim ad alias transeunt et ad priores redeunt. lacertae ut ea, quae sine pedibus sunt, circumflexu venerem novere.
english_text: above the said <dasypodum> generally the females come first, the males in the rest. and the bears, as has been said, lay humanized, the Irenaeus standing, both entwined with each other, the cats standing by the sea, the woman lying down, the foxes thrown on their sides, and the woman embracing the sea. the women of bulls and deer do not tolerate violence; for that reason they enter into the conception. the stags, in turn, pass to others and return to the former. I came to know the lizards that are without feet.

Paragraph: Omnia animalia quo maiora corpore, hoc minus fecunda. singulos gignunt elephanti, cameli, equi; acanthis duodenos, avis minima. ocissime pariunt quae plurimos gignunt. quo maius est animal, tanto diutius formatur in utero. diutius gestantur quibus longiora sunt vitae spatia, neque crescentium tempestiva ad generandum aetas.
english_text: All animals, the larger the body, the less fertile. elephants, camels, and horses give birth to each other; Acanthus twelve, the smallest bird. those which give birth to the most the larger the animal, the longer it is formed in the womb. they are worn longer by those who have longer periods of life, nor are they of the seasonable age of growing up to beget.

Paragraph: quae solidas habent ungulas, singulos; quae bisulcas, et geminos pariunt; quorum in digitos pedum fissura divisa est, e<t> numerosiora in fetu. sed superiora omnia perfectos edunt partus, haec inchoatos, in quo sunt genere leaenae, ursae; et vulpes informe etiam magis quam supra dicta parit, rarumque est videre parientem. postea lambendo calefaciunt fetus omnia ea et figurant. pariunt plurimum quaternos. caecos autem gignunt canes, lupi, pantherae, thoes.
english_text: which have solid hooves, each one; which give birth to bisulcas and twins; whose toes are divided by a fissure, e<t> more numerous in the offspring. but all the above are eaten when the birth is complete, the latter when the birth has begun, in which the lioness and the bear are of the genus; and the fox gives birth even more unformed than what has been said above, and it is rare to see one giving birth. afterwards, by licking, the fetus warms all these things and shapes them. they give birth to most of the four. but dogs, wolves, panthers, and wolves give birth to the blind.

Paragraph: Canum plura genera. Laconicae octavo mense utr<i>mque generant; ferunt LX diebus et plurimum III. ceterae canes et semenstres coitum patiuntur. inplentur omnes uno coitu. quae ante iustum tempus concepere, diutius caecos habent catul<o>s, e<t> omnes totidem diebus. existimantur in urina attollere crus fere semenstres; id est signum consummati virium roboris. feminae hoc idem sidentes.
english_text: There are several types of dogs. In the eighth month of Laconia, both of them give birth; they say 60 days and most 3 other dogs and half-breeds suffer intercourse. they are all filled with one union. those that conceive before the proper time, have longer blind kittens, e<t> all for the same number of days. they are supposed to raise the leg in the urine almost half a mile; that is the sign of the consummation of the power of strength. women sitting this same.

Paragraph: partus duodeni quibus numerosissimi, cetero quini, seni, aliquando singuli, quod prodigiosum putant, sicut omnes mares aut omnes feminas gigni. primos quo<s>que mares pariunt, in ceteris alternant. ineuntur a partu sexto mense. octonos Laconicae pariunt. propria in eo genere maribus labore salacitas. vivunt Laconici annis denis, feminae duodenis, cetera genera XV annis, aliquando et XX, nec tota sua aetate generant, fere a duodecimo desinentes.
english_text: the birth of the twelve, of which the most numerous, the rest of the five, the old, sometimes single, which they think is prodigious, as if all males or all females were born. the males are the first to give birth, and they alternate in the rest. they enter from birth in the sixth month. octogenarians give birth to Laconia. characteristic of that kind of male labor. The Laconians live ten years, the females twelve, the other races fifteen years, sometimes twenty, and they do not reproduce throughout their whole life, almost ending at twelve.

Paragraph: Felium et ichneumonum reliqua ut canum. vivunt annis senis. dasypodes omni mense pariunt et superfetant, sicut lepores. a partu statim inplentur; concipiunt quamvis ubera siccante fetu. pariunt <vero> caecos. elephanti, ut diximus, pariunt singulos magnitudine vituli trimenstris. cameli XII mensibus ferunt; a trimatu pariunt vere iterumque post annum inplentur a partu.
english_text: The cat and the rest of the ichneumon are like dogs. they live to old age. dasypods give birth every month and survive, like rabbits. they are filled immediately from birth; they conceive, although the breasts dry up. They give birth to the blind. Elephants, as we have said, give birth each to the size of a three-month-old calf. camels bear for 12 months; they give birth in the spring after being trimmed, and are filled again a year after giving birth.

Paragraph: equas autem post tertium dem<um> aut post unum ab enixu utiliter admitti putant coguntque invitas. <asinas> et septimo die concipere facillime creditur. equarum iubas tondere praecipiunt, ut asinorum coitum patiantur humilitate; comantes enim gloria superbire. a coitu solae animalium currunt exadvers<u>s aquilonem austrumve, prout marem aut feminam concepere. colorem ilico mutant, rubriore pilo vel quicumque sit pleniore: hoc argumento desinunt admittere, etiam <v>olentes. nec inpedit partus quasdam ab opere falluntque gravidae. vicisse Olympia praegnantem Echecratidis Thessali invenimus.
english_text: but after the third day or after one, they think that the mares are advantageously admitted by the horse, and they force them to be invited. <asinas> and it is believed to be most easy to conceive on the seventh day. they order the manes of the mares to be cut, that they may humbly suffer the intercourse of the asses; for they are proud of their glory. from the copulation of the animals alone they run opposite to the north or the south, according as they conceive a male or a female. they change their color at once, with redder hair, or whatever is fuller: they cease to admit this argument, even when they smell it. nor does it hinder the delivery of some of the pregnant women who fail from work. We find Echecratis of Thessaly pregnant after winning Olympias.

Paragraph: equos et canes et sues initum matutinum adpetere, feminas autem post meridiem blandiri diligentiores tradunt. equas domitas LX diebus equire ante quam gregales, sues tantum coitu spumam ore fundere, verrem subantis audita voce, ni admittatur, cibum non capere usque in maciem, feminas autem in tantum effer<a>ri, ut hominem lancinent, candida maxime veste indutum. rabies ea aceto mitigatur naturae adsperso.
english_text: horses and dogs and swine to receive the morning entrance, but the women in the afternoon are more careful to be flattered. mares should be tamed 60 days before they are herded, sows should only pour foam from their mouths at copulation, the whip at the sound of the underling's voice is not to be admitted, they should not take food until they are lean, but the females should be brought out so far as to lance a man, dressed in mostly white clothes. rabies is mitigated by vinegar sprinkled with nature.

Paragraph: aviditas coitus putatur et cibis fieri, sicut viro eruca, pecori caepa. quae ex feris mitigentur, non concipere, ut anseres, apros vero tarde et cervos nec nisi ab infantia educatos mirum est. quadripedum praegnantes venerem arcent praeter equam et suem; sed superfetant dasypus et lepus tantum.
english_text: Coitus is supposed to be greedy for food, as rockets for men, onions for cattle. It is surprising that things which are tamed from the wild cannot be conceived, such as geese, but wild boars are slow and stags are only brought up from childhood. pregnant quadrupeds, except the mare and the pig; but only the porcupine and the hare survive.

Paragraph: Quaecumque animal pariunt, in capita gignunt circumacto fetu sub enixum, alia<s> in utero porrect<o>. quadripedes gestantur extentis ad longitudinem cruribus et <ad> alvum suam adplicatis; homo in semet conglobatus inter duo genua naribus sitis.
english_text: Whatever animals give birth, they give birth to their heads when the fetus is surrounded under the support, others in the womb. they are carried on all fours, stretched out at length with their legs and folded <to> their belly; a man huddled together between two knees with his noses.

Paragraph: molas, de quibus ante diximus, gigni putant, ubi mulier non ex mare, verum ex semet ipsa tantum conceperit. ideo nec animari, quia non sit ex duobus, altricemque habere per se vitam illam quae satis arboribusque contingat. ex omnibus, quae perfectos fetus, <s>ue<s> tantu<m> et numerosos edunt, <na>m plures contra naturam solidipedum aut bisulcorum.
english_text: The mills, of which we have spoken before, are thought to be born when a woman has conceived only from her own seed, not from the sea. therefore neither should we be encouraged, because it is not from two, and the altruistic to have by itself that life which is sufficiently connected with trees. of all which they eat perfect offspring, so much and in great numbers, that many, contrary to nature, are solid-footed or bisulky.

Paragraph: Super cuncta est murium fetus, haut sine cunctatione dicendus, quamquam sub auctore Aristotele et Alexandri Magni militibus. generatio eorum lambendo constare, non coitu, dicitur. ex una genitos CXX tradiderunt, apud Persas vero praegnant<e>s in ventre parentis repertas.
english_text: It must be said without hesitation that it is above all things the offspring of mice, although under the authority of Aristotle and the soldiers of Alexander the Great. It is said that their generation is established by licking, not by intercourse. from one they gave birth to 120 children, but among the Persians the pregnant<e>s were found in the womb of the parent.

Paragraph: et salis gustatu fieri praegnantes opinantur. itaque desinit mirum esse unde vis tanta messes populetur murium agrestium, in quibus illud quoque adhuc latet, quonam modo illa multitudo repente occidat. nam nec exanimes reperiuntur neque extat qui murem hieme in agro effoderit. plurimi ita ad Troada proveniunt et iam inde fugaverunt incolas. proventus eorum siccitatibus. tradunt etiam obituris vermiculum in capite gigni. Aegypti muribus durus pilus sicut irenaceis. <i>idem bipedes ambulant ceu Alpini quoque.
english_text: and salt doses are thought to become pregnant. and so it ceases to be a wonder, whence such a great harvest is populated by wild mice, in which it also is still hidden, in what manner that multitude suddenly kills. for neither the lifeless are found, nor is there anyone who digs up a mouse in the field in winter. most of them thus come to Troas, and have already driven away the inhabitants from thence. the result of their drought. they also deliver a worm in the head of the dead child. The hair of the mice of Egypt is hard like that of the Irenaeus. They also walk bipedally as do the Alpines.

Paragraph: _ Cum diversi generis coiere animalia, ita demum generant, si tempus nascendi par habent. Quadripedum ova gignentium lacertas ore parere, ut creditur vulgo, Aristoteles negat. neque incubant e<ae>dem, oblitae quo sint in loco enixae, quoniam huic animali nulla memoria; itaque per se catuli erumpunt.
english_text: _ When animals of different kinds come together, they breed in the end, if they have the same time to be born. Aristotle denies that quadrupedal lizards that lay eggs with their mouths, as is commonly believed. nor do they incubate the same, forgetting the place in which they were buried, since this animal has no memory; therefore the cubs break out by themselves.

Paragraph: Anguem ex medulla hominis spinae gigni accepimus a multis. pleraque enim occulta et caeca origine proveniunt, etiam in quadripedum genere, sicut salamandrae, animal lacertae figura, stellatum, numquam nisi magnis imbribus proveniens et serenitate desinens. huic tantus rigor, ut ignem tactu restinguat non alio modo quam glacies. eiusdem sanie, quae lactea ore vomitur, quacumque parte corporis humani contacta toti defluunt pili, idque, quod contactum est, colorem in vitiliginem mutat.
english_text: We received from many a serpent born of the marrow of a man's spine. for most of them proceed from a hidden and blind origin, even in the quadrupeds, such as salamanders, an animal shaped like a lizard, starry, never proceeding except in great showers, and ending in serenity. this one is so rigid that it extinguishes fire by touch in no other way than ice. of the same pus, which is vomited out of the milky mouth, whatever part of the human body it contacts, the entire hair falls off, and that which is contacted changes its color into vitiligo.

Paragraph: Quaedam ergo gignuntur ex non genitis et sine ulla simili origine, ut supra dicta et quaecumque ver statumque tempus anni generant. ex his quaedam nihil gignunt ut salamandrae, neque est in <i>is masculum femininumve, sicut neque in anguillis omnibus<que> quae nec animal nec ovum ex sese generant. neutrum est et ostreis genus et ceteris adhaerentibus vado vel saxo.
english_text: Certain things, then, are born from the unborn, and without any similar origin, as was said above, and whatever spring and state of the year they generate. Some of these, like salamanders, do not produce anything, and there is neither male nor female in them, as neither in all eels, which produce neither an animal nor an egg from themselves. It is neither of the oysters' kind, nor of the others that stick to it.

Paragraph: quae autem per se generantur, si in mares et feminas discripta sunt, generant quidem aliquid coitu, sed inperfectum ac dissimile et ex quo nihil amplius gignatur, ut vermiculos muscae. id magis declara<b>it natura eorum quae insecta d<i>cuntur, arduae explanationis omnia et privatim dicato opere narranda. quapropter ingenium praedictorum et reliqua subtexetur edissertatio.
english_text: But those things which are generated by themselves, if they are divided into males and females, indeed generate something by intercourse, but imperfect and unlike, and from which nothing more is generated, like the worms of the fly. This is made more clear by the nature of what is said about insects, all of which are difficult to explain and to be told in a privately dedicated work. therefore the character of the aforesaid and the rest will be covered in the dissertation.

Paragraph: Ex sensibus ante cetera homini tactus, dein gustatus; reliquis superatur a multis. aquilae clarius cernunt, vultures sagacius odorantur, liquidius audiunt talpae: obrutae terra, tam denso atque surdo naturae elemento, praeterea voce omni in sublime tendente, sermonem exaudiunt et, si de iis loquare, intellegere etiam dicuntur et profugere.
english_text: Of the senses, before the rest, man was touched, then tasted; He is surpassed by many others. the eagles see more clearly, the vultures smell more discerningly, the moles hear more clearly: the ruined earth, so dense and deaf to the element of nature, moreover, hears the conversation of every voice tending to the sublime, and if they speak of them, they are said to understand and flee.

Paragraph: auditus cui hominum primo negatus est, huic et sermonis usus ablatus, nec sunt naturaliter surdi, ut non <i>idem sint et muti. in marinis ostreis auditum esse non est verisimile, sed ad sonum mergere se dicuntur solen<es>;
english_text: Hearing was first denied to men, and the use of speech was taken away from this, and they are not naturally deaf, so that they are not the same as dumb. It is not likely to have been heard of in sea-oysters, but they are said to sink to the sound;

Paragraph: ideo et silentium in more piscantibus. pisces quidem auditus nec membra habent nec foramina, audire tamen eos palam est, utp<o>te cum plausu congregari feros ad cibum adsuetudine in quibusdam vivariis spectetur et in piscinis Caesaris genera piscium ad nomen venire quosdamve singulos. itaque produntur etiam clarissime audire mugil, lupus, salpa, chromis et ideo in vado vivere.
english_text: therefore also the silence in the custom of those who fish. indeed, hearing fishes have neither limbs nor holes, yet it is plain to hear them, as it is seen that wild beasts are accustomed to be gathered together for food with applause in some fish-houses, and in Caesar's ponds the kinds of fish come to be named, or some individuals. therefore they are forced to hear very clearly the howling, the wolf, the salpa, and the croaks, and therefore live in the ford.

Paragraph: Olfactum <i>is esse manifeste patet, quippe non omnes eadem esca capiuntur et prius quam adpetant odorantur. quosdam et speluncis latentes salsamento inlitis faucibus scopuli piscator expellit velut sui cadaveris agnitionem fugientes, conveniuntque ex alto etiam ad quosdam odores, ut saepiam ustam et polypum, quae ideo coiciuntur in nassas. sentinae quidem navium odorem procul fugiunt,
english_text: It is plainly evident that it is the sense of smell, since not all are caught at the same bait and smelled before they seek it. and some, hidden in caves, the fisherman expels from the jaws of the rock, sprinkled with salt, as if fleeing from the recognition of his own corpse, and they come together from the depths even to certain odors, such as burnt cuttlefish and octopus, which are therefore thrown into the traps. the pumps, indeed, flee far away from the smell of ships,

Paragraph: maxime tamen piscium sanguinem. non potest petris avelli polypus; idem cunila admota ab odore protinus resilit. purpurae quoque faetidis capiuntur. nam de reliquo animalium genere quis dubitet? cornus cervini odore serpentes fugantur, sed maxime styracis; origani aut calcis aut sulpuris formicae necantur. culices acida petunt, ad dulcia non advolant. Tactus sensus omnibus est, etiam quibus nullus alius; nam et ostreis et terestrium vermibus quoque.
english_text: but especially the blood of fish. an octopus cannot be plucked from a rock; the same dog, moved by the smell, immediately bounced off. the purple ones are also caught in the stench. for who doubts about the rest of the species of animals? serpents are driven away by the scent of the stag's horns, but especially the styracs; ants are killed by oregano or lime or sulphur. gnats seek acid, they do not fly to sweets. The sense of touch is to all, even to whom no one else; for both oysters and terrestrial worms also.

Paragraph: Existimaverim omnibus sensum et gustatus esse. cur enim alios alia sapor<e>s adpetant? in quo vel praecipua naturae <v>ari<e>ta<s> et <lusu>s: alia dentibus praedantur, alia unguibus, alia rostri aduncitate carpunt, alia latitudine eruunt, alia acumine excavant, alia sugunt, alia lambunt, sorbent, mandunt, vorant. nec minor varietas in pedum ministerio, ut rapiant, distrahant, teneant, premant, pendeant, tellurem scabere non cessent.
english_text: I would have thought that everyone had sense and taste. for why do they seek other tastes? in which even the most important of the <v>ari<e>ta<s> and <lusu>s> of nature: some are preyed upon with the teeth, some with the claws, some are grasped with the hook of the beak, some are plucked out in breadth, some are excavated with a sharp point, some are sucked, some are licked up, they eat, they devour. and there was no less variety in the service of the feet, that they might seize, tear, hold, press, hang, and never cease to scratch the earth.

Paragraph: Venenis capreae et coturnices, ut diximus, pinguescunt, placidissima animalia, at serpentes ov<is>, spectanda quidem draconum arte: aut enim solida hauriunt, si iam fauces capiunt, quae deinde in semet convoluti frangunt intus atque ita putamina extussiunt, aut si tenerior est catulis adhuc aetas, orbe adprehensa spirae ita sensim vehementerque praestringunt, ut amputata parte ceu ferro e reliqua, quae amplexu tenetur, sorbeant. simili modo avibus devoratis solidis contentione plumam e<x>cita<m> revomunt.
english_text: The poisons of goats and quails, as we have said, make them fat, very placid animals, but snakes, indeed, look at the skill of dragons: for they either absorb solids, if they already take their mouths, which they then roll up into a seed and break inside and thus spit out the guts, or if they are more tender when the cubs are still young, the spirals, caught in the circle, tighten so slowly and violently that they suck the amputated part or the steel from the rest, which is held in the embrace. in the same way as birds devoured solids, they regurgitate their feathers with a struggle.

Paragraph: Scorpiones terra vivunt. serpentes, cum occasio est, vinum praecipue adpetunt, cum alioqui exiguo indigeant potu; eaedem minimo et paene nullo cibo, cum adservantur inclusae, sicuti aranei quoque, alioqui suctu viventes. ideo nullum interit fame aut siti venenatum. nam neque calor <i>is nec sanguis nec sudor, quae aviditatem naturali sale augent. in quo genere omnia magis exitialia, si
english_text: Scorpions live on earth. snakes, when there is an opportunity, are especially fond of wine, when otherwise they need a little drink; the same with very little and almost no food, when they are kept enclosed, like spiders also, otherwise living by sucking. therefore no one perishes poisoned by hunger or thirst. for it is neither heat, nor blood, nor sweat, which increase the appetite for natural salt. in which kind everything is more fatal, if

Paragraph: suum genus edere ante quam noceant. condit in thesauros maxillarum cibum sp<h>ingiorum et satyrorum genus, mox inde sensim ad mandendum manibus expr<o>mit, et quod formicis in annum, sollemne est his in dies vel horas. unum animal digitos habentium herba alitur, lepus; e<a> et fruge solidipedes, et e bisulcis sues omni cibatu et radicibus. solidipedum volutatio propria. serratorum dentium carnivora sunt omnia; ursi et fruge, fronde, vindemia, pomis vivunt et apibus, cancris etiam ac formicis; lupi, ut diximus, et terra in fame.
english_text: to eat their kind before they harm them. He stores in the treasures of his jaws the food of the species of sp<h>ings and satyrs, and soon from there he gradually expresses it with his hands to gnaw, and what ants do in a year, is solemn in these days or hours. one animal that has toes feeds on grass, the rabbit; and the harvest of solids, and of all the fodder and roots of the pigs. a characteristic roll of solid feet. all are carnivorous with serrated teeth; bears live on crops, leaves, vintages, apples, and bees, even crabs and ants; wolves, as we have said, and the earth in famine.

Paragraph: pecus potu pinguescit, ideo sal illis aptissimus; item veterina, quamquam et fruge et herba, s<cilicet> ut bibere, sic edunt. ruminant praeter iam dicta silvestrium cervi, cum a nobis aluntur, omnia autem iacentia potius quam stantia, et hieme magis quam aestate, septenis fere mensibus. Pontici quoque mures simili modo remandunt.
english_text: cattle grow fat with drink, therefore salt is most suitable for them; in the same way, animals, although both grain and grass, s<silicet> to drink, so they eat. Besides the wild deer already mentioned, they chew the cud when they are fed by us, but all lying down rather than standing, and in winter more than in summer, for about seven months. Pontic rats also row in a similar way.

Paragraph: In potu autem, quibus serrati dentes, lambunt et mures hi vulgares, quamvis ex alio genere sint. quibus continui dentes, sorbent, ut equi, boves. neutrum ursi, sed aquam quoque morsu vorant. in Africa maior pars ferarum aestate non bibunt inopia imbrium, quam ob causam capti mures Libyci, si bibere, moriuntur. or<y>gem perpetuo sitientia Africa<e> generant ex natura loci potu carentem et mirabili modo ad remedia sitientium: namque Gaetuli latrones eo durant auxilio, repertis <a>p<e>r<t>o corpore eorum saluberrimi liquoris vesicis.
english_text: And in the drink, in which their teeth are serrated, these common mice also lick, although they are of a different species. with which their teeth are continuous, they suck, as do horses and oxen. neither bear, but they also devour water with their bite. in Africa the greater part of the beasts will not drink in the summer for want of rain, for which reason the Libyan rats caught, if they drink, die. The perpetual thirst of Africa, by the nature of the place, is destitute of drink, and in a wonderful way to the remedies of the thirsty: for the robbers of the Gaetuli are sustained by that aid, having found in their bodies bladders of the most wholesome liquid.

Paragraph: Insidunt in eadem Africa pardi condensa<m> arbore<m> occultatique e<x> ramis in praetereuntia desiliunt atque e volucrum sede grassantur. feles quidem quo silentio, quam levibus vestigiis obrepunt avibus! quam occulte speculatae in musculos exiliunt! excrementa sua effossa obruunt terra, intellegentes odorem illum indicem sui esse.
english_text: In the same Africa, leopards hide in trees, and, hiding from the branches, they leap out of the passers-by, and from the perch of the birds they prey. cats, indeed, with what silence, how lightly they sneak up on the birds! how secretly spied on the muscles leap! they dig up their excrement and cover the earth, realizing that the smell is their index.

Paragraph: ergo et alios quosdam sensus esse quam supra dictos haut difficulter apparet. Sunt enim quaedam <i>is bella amicitiaeque, unde et adfectus, praeter illa quae de quibusque eorum suis diximus locis. dissident olores et aquilae, corvus et ch<l>oreus noctu invicem ova exquirentes, simili modo corvus et miluus, illo praeripiente huic cibos, cornices atque noctua, aquilae et trochilus, si credimus, quoniam rex appellatur avium, noctuae
english_text: therefore it appears with difficulty that there are certain other senses than those mentioned above. For there are certain wars and friendships, whence also affections, in addition to those of which we have said in their respective places. divers birds and eagles, the raven and the raven seeking each other's eggs at night, in like manner the raven and the blackbird, the one snatching food from the other, the cornice and the nightingale, the eagle and the thrush, if we believe that the king of birds is called the nightingale

Paragraph:
et ceterae minores aves, rursus cum tri mustela et cornix, turtur et pyrallis, icneumones vespae et phalangia   aranei, aquaticae
entos et gavia e harpe, et triorchis accipiter, sorices et ardiolae invicem fetibus insidiantes, _(aegithus avis minima cum asino; spinetis enim se scabendi causa atterens nidos eius dissipat, quod adeo pavet, ut voce omnino rudentis audita ova eiciat, pulli ipsi metu cadant; igitur advolans ulcera eius rostro excavat)_
english_text:
and the other smaller birds, again with the tri weasel and hornbill, the turtle and the pyral, the wasp's lungs and the phalanx of the spider, the aquatic
entos and the harp hawk, and the triorchis hawk, the shrews and the sardines lying in wait for each other's young, _(Aegitus the smallest bird with the ass; for by scratching himself with the thorns he destroys their nests, which is so terrified that when he hears the voice of the ruffian at all he casts out the eggs, the chicks themselves fall in fear; therefore flying over and excavating the sores on his beak)_

Paragraph: volpes et mil<u>i, angues et mustelae et sues. aesalon vocatur parva avis ova corvi frangens, cuius pulli infestantur a volpibus. invicem haec catulos eius ipsamque vellit; quod ubi viderunt corvi, contra auxiliantur velut adversus communem hostem. et acanthis in spinis vivit; idcirco asinos et ipsa odit flores spinae devorantes, aegithum vero in tantum, ut sanguinem eorum credant non coire multisque ideo veneficiis infament.
english_text: foxes and mil<u>i, snakes and weasels and swine. Aesalon is called a small bird that breaks the eggs of a crow, whose chicks are infested by foxes. these cubs of hers love each other; that when they see ravens, they help each other, as if against a common enemy. and acanthus lives in thorns; for this reason she also hates donkeys that devour the flowers of the thorn, but so much so that they believe that their blood does not conspire, and therefore many people are infamous for poisoning.

Paragraph: dissident thoes et leones, et minima aeque ac maxima. formicosam arborem urucae cavent. librat araneus se filo in caput serpentis porrectae sub umbra arboris suae tantaque vi morsu cerebrum adprehendit, ut stridens subinde et vertigine rotata ne filum quidem pendentis rumpere, adeo non fugere queat. nec finis ante mortem est.
english_text: odds are between the lions and the lions, and the smallest as well as the greatest. beware of the ant tree. The spider balances itself with a thread on the head of a snake stretched out under the shade of its tree, and with such force bites the brain, that it squeals from time to time and spins with vertigo, so that it cannot even break the hanging thread, so much so that it cannot flee. and there is no end before death.

Paragraph: Rursus amici pavones et columbae, turtures et psittaci, merulae et turtures, cornix et ardiolae contra volpium genus communibus inimicitiis, harpe et miluus contra triorchin. quid, non et adfectus indicia sunt etiam in serpentibus, inmitissimo animalium genere? dicta sunt quae Arcadia narrat de domino a dracone servato et agnito voce [draconis].
english_text: Friends again, peacocks and doves, turtles and parrots, blackbirds and turtledoves, hornbills and sardines against the common enmity of the fox race, the harp and the warbler against the triorchin. What, are there not signs of affection also in snakes, the most merciless class of animals? what Arcadia narrates about a lord saved by a dragon and recognized by the voice [of the dragon] have been said.

Paragraph: de aspide miraculum Phylarcho reddatur. is enim auctor est, cum ad mensam cuiusdam veniens in Aegypto aleretur adsidue enixa catulos, quorum ab uno filium hospitis interemptum, illam reversam ad consuetudinem cibi intellexisse culpam et necem intulisse catulo nec postea in tectum id reversam.
english_text: of the asp, a miracle is rendered to Phylarchus. for he is the author, when he came to the table of a certain one in Egypt, and was constantly fed by a strong cub, one of whom had killed the son of a guest, who, having returned to the habit of eating, understood the fault and brought the cub to death, and did not afterwards return it to the shelter.

Paragraph: Somni quaestio non obscuram coniectationem habet. in terrestribus omnia quae coniveant dormire manifestum est. aquatilia quoque exiguum quidem, etiam qui de ceteris dubitant, dormire tamen existimant, non oculorum argumento, quia non habent genas, verum ipsa quiete cernuntur placida ceu soporata neque aliud quam caudas moventia et ad tumultum aliquem expavescentia.
english_text: The problem of sleep does not have a dark meaning. It is clear that everything that comes together on earth sleeps. and even those who doubt the rest think that they are sleeping, not because of their eyes, because they have no cheeks, but they themselves are seen to be calm or asleep, and do nothing but move their tails and be alarmed at any disturbance.

Paragraph: de thynnis confidentius adfirmatur; iuxta ripas enim aut petras dormiunt, plani autem piscium in vado, ut manu saepe tollantur. nam delphini ballaenaeque stertentes etiam audiuntur. insecta quoque dormire silentio apparet, quae ne luminibus quidem admotis excitentur.
english_text: it is affirmed more confidently of the thynns; for they sleep near the banks or rocks, but the flat fish in the ford, so that they are often lifted by hand. for dolphins and whales are also heard snorting. insects also seem to sleep in silence, which are not even stirred up by the stirring of lights.

Paragraph: Homo genitus premitur somno per aliquot menses, dein longior in dies vigilia. somniat statim infans; nam et pavore expergiscitur et suctum imitatur. quidam vero numquam, quibus mortiferum fuisse signum contra consuetudinem somnium invenimus exempla. magnus hic in vita locus et diversis refertus documentis, utrumne sint aliqua praescita animi quiescentis, qua<e> fiant ratione, an fortuita res sit ut pleraque. si exemplis agatur, profecto paria fiant. a v<i>no et a cibis proxima atque in redormitione vana esse visa prope convenit. est autem somnus nihil aliud quam animi in medium sese recessus.
english_text: A man born is pressed into sleep for several months, and then wakes for longer days. let the child dream at once; for he wakes up with fear and imitates the sucker. but some never, in which we find examples of dreams that were a sign of death against the custom. Hae pariunt, in terram demisso spinae caule, ova condensa autumni tempore. ea durant hieme; e terra subsequenti anno exitu veris emittunt parvas, nigrantes et sine cruribus pinnisque reptantes. itaque vernis aquis intereunt
english_text: The feet of insects, as they are, move sideways. the longer ends of some are bent outwards, like locusts. These give birth, when the stem of a thorn is lowered into the ground, and the eggs are condensed in the season of autumn. they last in winter; from the ground in the spring of the following year, they send forth small, black, crawling creatures without legs or fins. therefore they perish with the waters of the spring

english_text: cis in India they are said to be a pint of feet in length, and to provide the use of saws for the legs and thighs, when they are bare. there is another death for them: they are carried by the wind in groups and fall into the seas or ponds. perhaps this happened, not, as the ancients supposed, by the wings being moistened with the moisture of the night. For the same reason they did not allow them to fly at night because of the cold, and they were unaware that distant seas had to be crossed by them, after many days of hunger, which we are most surprised by.

Paragraph: quoque, quam propter externa pabula petere sciunt. deorum irae pestis ea intellegitur. namque et grandiores cernuntur et tanto volant pinnarum stridore, ut [aliae] alites credantur, solemque obumbran<t> sollicitis suspectantibus populis, ne suas operiant terras. sufficiunt quippe vires et, tamquam parum sit maria transisse, inmensos tractus permeant diraque messibus nube contegunt, multa contactu adurentes, omnia vero morsu erodentes et fores quoque tectorum.
english_text: also, which they know how to ask for external fodder. it is understood as the plague of the wrath of the gods. for they are seen to be even larger, and fly with such a noise of their fins, that they are believed to be [other] fans, and shade the sun from the anxious and suspicious peoples, lest they cover their lands. for their strength is sufficient, and, as if they had scarcely crossed the seas, they penetrate immense tracts and cover with a cloud of terrible harvests, burning many by contact, but eroding everything with their bite, and the doors of the roofs also.

Paragraph: Italiam ex Africa maxime coortae infestant, saepe populo R<omano> ad Sibyllina coacto remedia confugere inopiae metu. in Cyrenaica regione lex etiam est ter anno debellandi eas, primo ova obterendo, dein fetum, postremo adul-
english_text: Italy was infested chiefly by storms from Africa, often forcing the Roman people to flee to the Sibyllines for fear of want of remedies. in the region of Cyrenaica it is also a law to exterminate them three times a year, first by cutting the eggs, then the fetus, and lastly the adult

Paragraph: Vox earum proficisci ab occipitio videtur. eo loco in commissura scapularum habere quasi dentes existimantur eosque inter se terendo stridorem edere, circa duo maxime aequinoctia, sicut cicadae circa solstitium. coitus locustarum qui et insectorum omnium quae coeunt, marem portante femina, in eum feminarum ultimo caudae reflexo tardoque digressu. minores autem in omni hoc genere feminis mares.
english_text: Their voice seems to come from behind. at that point they are supposed to have teeth in the joint of the shoulders, and by grinding them together they make a grinding noise, especially about the two equinoxes, like cicadas about the solstice. the mating of locusts and all the insects that mate, the female carrying the male, and the females moving towards him with the last reflection of their tails and a slow retreat. but in all this species the males are smaller than the females.

Paragraph: Indicae formicae cornua Erythris in aede Herculis fixa miraculo fuere. aurum hae cavernis egerunt terra in regione septentrionalium Indorum qui Dardae vocantur. ipsis color felium, magnitudo Aegypti luporum. erutum hoc ab iis tempore hiberno Indi furantur aestivo fervore, conditis propter vaporem in cuniculos formicis, quae tamen odore sollicitatae provolant crebroque lacerant quamvis praevelocibus camelis fugientes. tanta pernicitas feritasque est cum amore auri.
english_text: The horns of the Indian ants were miraculously fixed in the house of Hercules. These caves produced gold in the country of the northern Indians, who are called Dardas. the color of cats, the size of the wolves of Egypt. This the Indians snatched away from them in the winter season, in the heat of the summer, they put them in tunnels for the sake of the steam, which, however, alarmed by the smell, drive out and tear them often, although they are fleeing on very swift camels. there is so much destruction and cruelty with the love of gold.

Paragraph: Multa autem insecta et aliter nascuntur, atque in primis e rore. insidet hic raphani folio primo vere et spissatus sole in magnitudinem milii cogitur. inde porrigitur vermiculus parvus et triduo mox uruca, quae adiectis diebus accrescit, inmobilis, duro cortice. ad tactum tantum movetur, araneo accreta, quam chrysallidem appellant. rupto deinde cortice volat papilio.
english_text: But many insects are born in other ways, and in the first place from dew. here it sits on a leaf of radish in the first spring and is forced by the sun to the size of a millet. from there a small worm is stretched out, and after three days the caterpillar grows, which, in the additional days, grows into an immobile, hard shell. it is moved only by the touch, and is attracted by the spider, which they call a chrysalis. then the butterfly flies out of the bark.

Paragraph: Sic quaedam ex imbri generantur in terra, quaedam et in ligno. nec enim cossi tantum in eo, sed etiam tabani ex eo nascuntur et alias, ubicumque umor est nimius, sicut intra hominem taeniae tricenum pedum,
english_text: Thus, some of the rains are generated on the earth, and some on the wood. for not only the cocci in it, but also the tabani are born from it, and elsewhere, wherever there is too much moisture, as within a man of three feet of tape.

This poison has remedies with it: the wings are healed, by which it is fatal. Again, nature brings forth other kinds of gnats, since in the snow they are found to be older red worms, and the snow itself turns red with age, with hairs of wool, white indeed, and larger and duller in the Middle Ages.

Paragraph: Gignit aliqua et contrarium naturae elementum. siquidem in Cypri aerariis fornacibus et medio igni maioris muscae magnitudinis volat pinnatum quadrupes; appellatur pyrallis, a quibusdam pyroto<con>. quamdiu est in igni, vivit; cum evasit longiore paulo volatu, emoritur.
english_text: It produces some and the opposite element of nature. indeed, in the brass furnaces of Cyprus, and in the midst of the fire, there flies a fly of greater size, a winged quadruped; it is called pyrallis, by some pyroto<con>. as long as it is in the fire, it lives; when he had escaped by a little longer flight, he died.

Paragraph: Hypanis fluvius in Ponto circa solstitium defert acinorum effigie tenues membranas, quibus erumpit volucre quadrupes supra dicti modo, nec ultra unum diem vivit, unde hemerobion vocatur. reliquis talium ab initio ad finem septenarii sunt numeri, culici et vermiculi<s> ter septeni, corpus parientibus quater septeni; mutationes et in alias figuras transitus trinis aut quadrinis diebus. cetera ex his pinnata autumno fere moriuntur tab<e alarum>, <tab>ani quidem etiam caecitate. muscis umore exanimatis, si cinere condantur, redit vita.
english_text: The river Hypanis in Pontus, about the solstice, carries thin membranes in the shape of acorns, with which it bursts forth into four-legged birds in the manner aforesaid, and does not live more than one day, whence it is called Hemerobion. for the rest of these, from the beginning to the end of the septenary, the number of the gnat and the worm is three seven, and the body of those who give birth four seven; changes and transitions into other figures in three or four days. the rest of these pinnats generally die in the autumn of tab<e alarum>, and <tab>ani also of blindness. If the flies, deadened by the moisture, are buried in ashes, life returns.
